They have been sufficiently regaled throughout the day; the food thus finally distributed is to be carried home. The women pack it into their string bags and prepare to move off. Men and children will bear their part. One remembers the spectacle of a diminutive child bearing away the blood-spattered head of a huge pig, balanced with difficulty and pride upon his own small crown. Thus laden with proofs of friendship the guests depart to await the time when, in a year or so, they will make a similar return of hospitality.' [307]//Feasts were held on multiple occasions: 'In pre-European times, according to present-day informants, the most important feasts held by the Orokaiva people were associated with initiation, marriage, death (though apparently not birth), and the enhancement of prestige. Feasts were also held to mark the transfer of land, the re-establishment of peace between persons who had been quarrelling, resumption of residence after a prolonged absence, and the lifting of prohibitions between a man and his mother-in-law.' [308]//There may have been considerable change in the scale and types of feasts celebrated in the colonial period: 'It is impossible to know with any certainty the scale of feasting prior to European contact for, though a detailed study of these people was made in the late 1920s (Williams 1928 and 1930). Government patrols had brought tribal fighting to a halt some years before. It is therefore quite likely that, with less time taken up in warfare and greater freedom of movement assured, the feasts and ceremonies of that day were more elaborate than those of the precontact era.' [309]//Williams reports ritualized declarations of loyalty, but also claims that underlying wariness between guests and hosts was common: 'Again all the underlings of any ‘big man’ will be known to others under his name. In the Sangara dialect there is a word tekahoka, of which I do not know the literal meaning, but which appears to stand for a ‘following’. When, at a gathering of the clans for war, or for some peaceful ceremony, [Page 104] the several parties make their appearance each following in single file behind its leader, a cry will go up, ‘Here come the people, the Tekahoka, of Embuja, of Ehari, of Andari!’-whoever the big man may be. So in the Aiga language there is a word ambotani, which embraces all a man's junior relatives; and thus a number of more or less unimportant individuals may be known to others as the juniors of a certain big man and identified by his name.' [310] 'Treachery, of which one or two examples have been given (pp. 166-7), was not regarded as contemptible, and according to Beaver, as we have seen, one kind of homicidal emblem was specially assigned to the slayer of a peace emissary. Towards all outsiders the correct attitude was one of suspicion if not always of hostility; a complete stranger wandering alone would be regarded both as potential enemy and good meat; and when visitors came in friendship, as at a feast, there was never any lack of warlike readiness on either side. The very cries of welcome which are so characteristic of the Orokaiva are possibly a sign of the dormant hostility between guest and host, being recognizable in one case at least as meant for reassurance of the former regarding the intentions of the latter.' [311]
♠ Frequency for the ritual specialist ♣ yearly ♥ Given how feasts were performed on multiple occasions, we have assumed that feasts were held more often than once per generation but less often than monthly: 'In pre-European times, according to present-day informants, the most important feasts held by the Orokaiva people were associated with initiation, marriage, death (though apparently not birth), and the enhancement of prestige. Feasts were also held to mark the transfer of land, the re-establishment of peace between persons who had been quarrelling, resumption of residence after a prolonged absence, and the lifting of prohibitions between a man and his mother-in-law.' [312] NOTE: We have no records describing how this ritual was performed in pre-colonial times--instead, our main sources date to the twentieth century [313][314]
♠ Frequency per participant ♣ yearly ♥ Given how feasts were performed on multiple occasions, we have assumed that feasts were held more often than once per generation but less often than monthly: 'In pre-European times, according to present-day informants, the most important feasts held by the Orokaiva people were associated with initiation, marriage, death (though apparently not birth), and the enhancement of prestige. Feasts were also held to mark the transfer of land, the re-establishment of peace between persons who had been quarrelling, resumption of residence after a prolonged absence, and the lifting of prohibitions between a man and his mother-in-law.' [315] NOTE: We have no records describing how this ritual was performed in pre-colonial times--instead, our main sources date to the twentieth century [316][317]
♠ Frequency for the audience ♣ yearly ♥ Given how feasts were performed on multiple occasions, we have assumed that feasts were held more often than once per generation but less often than monthly: 'In pre-European times, according to present-day informants, the most important feasts held by the Orokaiva people were associated with initiation, marriage, death (though apparently not birth), and the enhancement of prestige. Feasts were also held to mark the transfer of land, the re-establishment of peace between persons who had been quarrelling, resumption of residence after a prolonged absence, and the lifting of prohibitions between a man and his mother-in-law.' [318] NOTE: We have no records describing how this ritual was performed in pre-colonial times--instead, our main sources date to the twentieth century [319][320]
♠ Duration ♣ suspected unknown ♥
♠ Typical size of participating group ♣ suspected unknown ♥ in absolute numbers. 'It is impossible to know with any certainty the scale of feasting prior to European contact for, though a detailed study of these people was made in the late 1920s (Williams 1928 and 1930). Government patrols had brought tribal fighting to a halt some years before. It is therefore quite likely that, with less time taken up in warfare and greater freedom of movement assured, the feasts and ceremonies of that day were more elaborate than those of the precontact era.' [321]
♠ Inclusiveness (ritual specialist) ♣ substantial minority ♥ 'Though the pondo kiari embo tends to be a man of much influence in the village, he does not normally have any authority over resources held by any extended family other than his own. It is only for the specific purpose of feast-giving that he is given such authority, and it is limited in time from the meeting just described until the day of the feast itself. The meeting thus temporarily changes the authority structure of the village. The growing taro crop and the available pigs become, at least ideally, the corporate property of the village, whereas normally they are family property. The pondo kiari embo becomes, at least formally and ritually, the controller of this property. The unit of the group of offerers of the sacrifice is a necessary condition for the success of the rituals that follow.' [322] NOTE: We have no records describing how this ritual was performed in pre-colonial times--instead, our main sources date to the twentieth century [323][324]
♠ Inclusiveness (participants) ♣ whole polity ♥ The following quote suggests that men, women and children participated: 'As it was explained (whether naïvely or waggishly) on one occasion, fresh entrails are suitable for men; if they stink a little they are suitable for women; and if they stink a great deal they will do for the children.' [325] NOTE: We have no records describing how this ritual was performed in pre-colonial times--instead, our main sources date to the twentieth century [326][327]
♠ Inclusiveness (audience) ♣ whole polity ♥ The following quote suggests that no specific group was excluded from the festivities: 'As it was explained (whether naïvely or waggishly) on one occasion, fresh entrails are suitable for men; if they stink a little they are suitable for women; and if they stink a great deal they will do for the children.' [328] NOTE: We have no records describing how this ritual was performed in pre-colonial times--instead, our main sources date to the twentieth century [329][330]
Dysphoric elements
♠ fasting ♣ inferred absent ♥ 'Towards the end of the day comes the formal distribution of food. The master of the feast, conferring anxiously with his friends, has been setting out the taro in heaps, making them correspond by laborious arithmetic with the number of his principal guests. Now that the tally appears satisfactory, he turns, with an enthusiasm bordering on violence, to the distribution. With loud shouts he and his assistants rush back and forth depositing, or often rather hurling down, bunches of taro before the guests, who accept them with a fitting appearance of indifference. In the same way the pig flesh-legs, quarters, chines, and entrails-are bestowed on top of the taro heaps, and the guests are ready to depart. They have been sufficiently regaled throughout the day; the food thus finally distributed is to be carried home. The women pack it into their string bags and prepare to move off. Men and children will bear their part. One remembers the spectacle of a diminutive child bearing away the blood-spattered head of a huge pig, balanced with difficulty and pride upon his own small crown. Thus laden with proofs of friendship the guests depart to await the time when, in a year or so, they will make a similar return of hospitality.' [331] NOTE: We have no records describing how this ritual was performed in pre-colonial times--instead, our main sources date to the twentieth century [332][333]

Feasts were also held to mark the transfer of land, the re-establishment of peace between persons who had been quarrelling, resumption of residence after a prolonged absence, and the lifting of prohibitions between a man and his mother-in-law.' [342]//
Euphoric elements
♠ feasting ♣ inferred present ♥ 'Towards the end of the day comes the formal distribution of food. The master of the feast, conferring anxiously with his friends, has been setting out the taro in heaps, making them correspond by laborious arithmetic with the number of his principal guests. Now that the tally appears satisfactory, he turns, with an enthusiasm bordering on violence, to the distribution. With loud shouts he and his assistants rush back and forth depositing, or often rather hurling down, bunches of taro before the guests, who accept them with a fitting appearance of indifference. In the same way the pig flesh-legs, quarters, chines, and entrails-are bestowed on top of the taro heaps, and the guests are ready to depart. They have been sufficiently regaled throughout the day; the food thus finally distributed is to be carried home. The women pack it into their string bags and prepare to move off. Men and children will bear their part. One remembers the spectacle of a diminutive child bearing away the blood-spattered head of a huge pig, balanced with difficulty and pride upon his own small crown. Thus laden with proofs of friendship the guests depart to await the time when, in a year or so, they will make a similar return of hospitality.' [343] NOTE: We have no records describing how this ritual was performed in pre-colonial times--instead, our main sources date to the twentieth century [344][345]

We have provisionally coded present, but this is open to review. ♠ obligations to each other's families ♣ inferred present ♥ The sponsoring of redistributive feasts displayed the host's generosity and affirmed existing obligations between allied groups [360].
♠ other ♣ ♥
♠ Orthopraxy checks ♣ inferred present ♥ The following quote suggests that the master of the feast was in charge of making sure that food was distributed correctly. 'Towards the end of the day comes the formal distribution of food. The master of the feast, conferring anxiously with his friends, has been setting out the taro in heaps, making them correspond by laborious arithmetic with the number of his principal guests. Now that the tally appears satisfactory, he turns, with an enthusiasm bordering on violence, to the distribution. With loud shouts he and his assistants rush back and forth depositing, or often rather hurling down, bunches of taro before the guests, who accept them with a fitting appearance of indifference. In the same way the pig flesh-legs, quarters, chines, and entrails-are bestowed on top of the taro heaps, and the guests are ready to depart. They have been sufficiently regaled throughout the day; the food thus finally distributed is to be carried home. The women pack it into their string bags and prepare to move off. Men and children will bear their part. One remembers the spectacle of a diminutive child bearing away the blood-spattered head of a huge pig, balanced with difficulty and pride upon his own small crown. Thus laden with proofs of friendship the guests depart to await the time when, in a year or so, they will make a similar return of hospitality.' [361] NOTE: We have no records describing how this ritual was performed in pre-colonial times--instead, our main sources date to the twentieth century [362][363]
♠ Orthodoxy checks ♣ inferred absent ♥ Inferred from the fact that this is not mentioned in Williams and Murray's account of this ritual [364]. However, Williams and Murray' account dates to the early twentieth century.
Costs of participation
♠ currency ♣ inferred absent ♥ No formal currency was present.
♠ property/valuable items ♣ inferred present ♥ Feasts were costly and required the accumulation of food for the purpose of redistribution: 'There is little to say concerning the harvesting. A woman gathers from time to time enough for her family's immediate wants, and the taro tops will be replanted. There are thus a number of plots at different stages of advancement in every woman's garden. Sometimes, however, when all the gardens of a clan are well stocked, there will be a simultaneous harvesting to furnish forth a feast. The products of the garden are then loaded ostentatiously upon platforms in the village before their final distribution to the guests.' [365] NOTE: We have no records describing how this ritual was performed in pre-colonial times--instead, our main sources date to the twentieth century [366][367]
♠ health costs ♣ inferred absent ♥ Inferred from the fact that this is not mentioned in Williams and Murray's account of this ritual [368]. However, Williams and Murray' account dates to the early twentieth century.
♠ animal sacrifice ♣ inferred present ♥ Pigs were sacrificed and consumed: 'The pig is carried in the usual manner, with its feet bound to a pole. For a long journey a pig-litter (kakate) may be used. It is a cage-like structure of cane which, as it were, is made to measure and fits closely about the animal's body (see p. 79). The conventional method of slaughtering is with the spear, and at a feast of importance this is done ceremonially, a number of pigs being set in a row and stuck simultaneously. On such an occasion I have seen one of the butchers, more elderly than the rest, fail to impart sufficient force to his thrust, and try again, amid a good deal of laughter, until he drove the point home. Then he levered the shaft of his weapon back and forth like a crow-bar to make his work the surer. On the whole, however, there is no special inhumanity in the treatment of pigs.' [369] NOTE: We have no records describing how this ritual was performed in pre-colonial times--instead, our main sources date to the twentieth century [370][371]
♠ human sacrifice of an out-group member ♣ inferred absent ♥ Inferred from the fact that this is not mentioned in Williams and Murray's account of this ritual [372]. However, Williams and Murray' account dates to the early twentieth century.
♠ human sacrifice of an in-group member ♣ inferred absent ♥ Inferred from the fact that this is not mentioned in Williams and Murray's account of this ritual [373]. However, Williams and Murray' account dates to the early twentieth century.
♠ human sacrifice of a relative ♣ inferred absent ♥ Inferred from the fact that this is not mentioned in Williams and Murray's account of this ritual [374]. However, Williams and Murray' account dates to the early twentieth century.
♠ other ♣ ♥

Most widespread collective ritual of the official cult[edit]

♠ Name ♣ Embahi separation ceremony ♥ 'Initiates are brought from the bush into the village. Having entered the village, they form two advancing lines until a large scaffolding is reached, erected at one end of the village. Turning, the men kneel down facing the entrance from which they have come and remain in this position, still keeping silence. It is at this stage that the candidates are presented. Faint cries arise from the bush, becoming louder and louder, and the words “Shi! Shi!” mingled with yells and shrieks are distinguished, and at the same time the candidates are marshalled in, led by their guides. They advance between the lines of men who, hitherto silent, now break up into groups, each catching a lad and running madly up and down the village, followed by the women, waving spears and all uttering cries and yells and rubbing the youngsters' arms, legs, and bodies. They now make a wild rush towards the scaffolding, throwing the lads on it, who endeavour to climb up out of reach, but are torn back by the mob and undergo further agony, until, utterly exhausted with fright and fatigue, they are allowed to climb away. Still retaining their group formation, the men rush forward to the scaffold uttering horrible yells, waving their heads sideways with faces upturned to the lads, and swinging their clubs, only to retreat again. This violence and pandemonium continue through the night. At daybreak the girl candidates are led in and subjected to the same treatment in somewhat milder form. Then the candidates, male and female, are mustered on the ohu platform, where they sit completely covered with hoods of bark-cloth. Trees are pulled down in the village.' [375]
♠ Frequency for the ritual specialist ♣ once per generation ♥ According to variable 'Typical frequency of participation for average participant' in the Ritual Database [376], this ritual occurs 'less often than annually but usually more often than once in a lifetime'. However, this is based on a twentieth-century source [377].
♠ Frequency per participant ♣ once in a lifetime ♥ According to variable 'Typical frequency of participation for average participant' in the Ritual Database [378], this ritual occurs 'once in a lifetime'. However, this is based on a twentieth-century source [379].
♠ Frequency for the audience ♣ once per generation ♥ (Giuseppe Innamorato: Discussed with RAs, unsure about textual reference on the existence of a passive audience, further research needed.). However,the group of initiands is ritually ‘harrassed’ by a group of men from their community. If the other people from the village are passive onlookers who watch the proceedings, they qualify as an audience. Will refer to Ritual Database. According to variable 'Typical frequency of participation for average participant' in the Ritual Database [380], this ritual occurs 'less often than annually but usually more often than once in a lifetime'. However, this is based on a twentieth-century source [381]. Inferred from the fact that both adolescents and adults, men and women, could participate [382]. However, this is based on a twentieth-century source [383].
♠ Duration ♣ 13 ♥ Estimate in hours. According to the 'Ritual duration category' of the Ritual Database [384], this ritual is coded as 'more than 12 hours'. However, this is based on a twentieth-century source [385].
♠ Typical size of participating group ♣ 50 ♥ in absolute numbers. According to the Ritual Database [386], 'Some members of community (<50%) where that is more than 15 persons'. 50 is a very rough estimate. Also, this is based on a twentieth-century source [387].
♠ Inclusiveness (ritual specialist) ♣ majority ♥ Both men and women appear to participate as specialists in this ritual [388]. However, this is based on a twentieth-century source [389].
♠ Inclusiveness (participants) ♣ whole polity ♥ Both adolescents and adults, men and women, participated [390]. However, this is based on a twentieth-century source [391].
♠ Inclusiveness (audience) ♣ whole polity ♥ (Giuseppe Innamorato: Discussed with RAs, unsure about textual reference on the existence of a passive audience, further research needed.). However,the group of initiands is ritually ‘harrassed’ by a group of men from their community. If the other people from the village are passive onlookers who watch the proceedings, they qualify as an audience. Will refer to Ritual Database.
Dysphoric elements
♠ fasting ♣ inferred present ♥ The variable 'fasting' in the Ritual Database [392] is coded as 'present'. However, this is based on a twentieth-century source [393].
♠ vigil/sleep deprivation ♣ inferred present ♥ The variable 'Sleep deprivation' in the Ritual Database [394] is coded as 'present'. However, this is based on a twentieth-century source [395].
♠ fear ♣ inferred present ♥ The variable 'Threats or actions that evince fear' in the Ritual Database [396] is coded as 'present'. However, this is based on a twentieth-century source [397].
♠ humiliation ♣ present ♥ The variable 'Humiliation of participants' in the Ritual Database [398] is coded as 'absent'. However, this is based on a twentieth-century source [399]. Thomas Cressy: The participants, both male and female, are ritually chased, harassed, scared, yelled at by a mob of men. For this reason, I have changed the code to present to reflect this ritual humiliation.
♠ disgust ♣ inferred absent ♥ The variable 'Mention of disgust' in the Ritual Database [400] is coded as 'absent'. However, this is based on a twentieth-century source [401].
♠ poisoning/dysphoria-causing drugs ♣ inferred absent ♥ (e.g. vomiting) 'Vomiting', 'Intake of hallucinogenic drugs', and 'Intake of sedatives' are all coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [402]. However, this is based on a twentieth-century source [403].
♠ pain ♣ inferred present ♥ 'Other' negatively valenced bodily stimulation is coded in the Ritual Database [404] as 'present'. 'Other uncomfortable experience', 'Burning of participants', 'Significant wound or bleeding', and 'Superficial wound' are coded as absent, but 'Whipping/ beating of participants' is coded as present. The average peak dysphoria rating in the Ritual Database [405] is medium-high 4.33. However, this is based on a twentieth-century source [406].
♠ mutilation ♣ inferred absent ♥ 'Burning of participants', 'Significant wound or bleeding', 'Superficial wound', 'Piercing', 'Scarification', 'Tattooing', 'Laceration of sensitive organs (skin, tongue, etc.)', and 'Circumcision/ removal of uvula' are all coded in the Ritual Database [407] as 'absent'. However, this is based on a twentieth-century source [408].
♠ risk of death ♣ inferred absent ♥ Activities that may result in excessive blood loss or deadly infection are coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [409], including 'Significant wound or bleeding', 'Superficial wound', 'Whipping/ beating of participants', 'Piercing', Scarification', 'Tattooing', 'Laceration of sensitive organs (skin, tongue, etc.)', and 'Circumcision/ removal of uvula'. However, this is based on a twentieth-century source [410].
♠ other ♣ present ♥ General rough treatment: 'They advance between the lines of men who, hitherto silent, now break up into groups, each catching a lad and running madly up and down the village, followed by the women, waving spears and all uttering cries and yells and rubbing the youngsters' arms, legs, and bodies. They now make a wild rush towards the scaffolding, throwing the lads on it, who endeavour to climb up out of reach, but are torn back by the mob and undergo further agony, until, utterly exhausted with fright and fatigue, they are allowed to climb away.' [411] However, this is an extract from a twentieth-century source [412].
Euphoric elements
♠ feasting ♣ inferred absent ♥ 'Some participants eat meal together' in the Ritual Database [413] is coded as 'absent'. However, this is based on a twentieth-century source [414].
♠ alcohol ♣ inferred absent ♥ Ritual Database [415] variable 'Intake of alcohol' is coded as 'absent'. However, this is based on a twentieth-century source [416].
♠ euphoria-inducing drugs (other than alcohol) ♣ inferred absent ♥ 'Intake of hallucinogenic drugs', and 'Intake of sedatives' are all coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [417]. However, this is based on a twentieth-century source [418].
♠ sex ♣ inferred absent ♥ 'Sexual intercourse' is coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [419]. However, this is based on a twentieth-century source [420].
♠ dancing ♣ inferred absent ♥ Ritual Database [421] variable 'Dancing or repetitive rhythmic movement' is coded as 'absent'. However, this is based on a twentieth-century source [422].

♠ entertainment ♣ inferred absent ♥ Not mentioned by source--which, it should be said, dates to the early twentieth century [427].
♠ other ♣ ♥
Cohesion
♠ honour code ♣ suspected unknown ♥ Difficult to code: initiation rituals often foster some kind of cohesion, but the source [428] provides no useful information in this regard. Also, the source dates to the early twentieth century.

♠ enemies of any group member are my enemies ♣ suspected unknown ♥ Difficult to code: initiation rituals often foster some kind of cohesion, but the source [431] provides no useful information in this regard. Also, the source dates to the early twentieth century.

♠ Orthopraxy checks ♣ inferred present ♥ Both men and women appear to participate as specialists in this ritual [434]. However, this is based on a twentieth-century source [435]. Presence of ritual specialists.

Costs of participation
♠ currency ♣ absent ♥ No formal currency is present.
♠ property/valuable items ♣ inferred absent ♥ Not mentioned by source--which, it should be said, dates to the early twentieth century [438].
♠ health costs ♣ present ♥ Participants are whipped and beaten. However, this is based on a twentieth-century source [439].
♠ animal sacrifice ♣ inferred absent ♥ 'Sacrifice of animals' is coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [440]. However, this is based on a twentieth-century source [441].
♠ human sacrifice of an out-group member ♣ inferred absent ♥ 'Sacrifice of humans' is coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [442]. However, this is based on a twentieth-century source [443].
♠ human sacrifice of an in-group member ♣ inferred absent ♥ 'Sacrifice of humans' is coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [444]. However, this is based on a twentieth-century source [445].
♠ human sacrifice of a relative ♣ inferred absent ♥ 'Sacrifice of humans' is coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [446]. However, this is based on a twentieth-century source [447].
♠ other ♣ ♥

Most frequent collective ritual of the official cult[edit]

Code the variables below for the most frequent collective ritual of the official cult.

♠ Name ♣ ♥ The ethnography reports a variety of spells and practices associated with garden magic: 'It would be possible to digress too widely upon the subject of garden magic, but no description of the gardener's methods would be complete without a reference to those processes which in our eyes are magic, but in his are common sense. We have seen that he has no real knowledge of fertilizing, but nevertheless he makes continual use of magical fertilizers. Into the hole prepared for the taro he may drop a fragment of some leaf before planting. Such leaves, called ba sivo, ‘taro medicine’, are of many and various kinds. There is in fact a particular plant which goes by the name of Ba-sivo, but any other leaf which will promote a vigorous growth of the taro is, ipso facto, ba sivo. The knowledge of some is common property, others are secret; all are of course magical and useless. The justification for their use, so far as it is made explicit, appears to have resided originally in a point of resemblance. Thus, for instance, one reliable ba sivo was said to be Iori bahiva. This is in fact a strong flourishing plant that grows by the water, much larger and ranker than the taro, but possessing a sufficient resemblance to it in leaf and stalk. It is felt that a fragment of Iori bahiva, planted together with the taro, will make the latter grow like the former, which the gardener, with more of hope than of reasoned confidence, has set it for a model. So we find the leaf of a large tree like Boruga used for ba sivo. The idea is not exactly that the taro will ‘wax a great tree’, but simply that it will grow strongly. A kai-sivo, or yam medicine, was, on the same principle-if we can use that word for such a hazy mental association-a certain vigorous trailing plant called Hupo. There is a more elementary form of magic than this [Page 147] of the fertilizer. The first component of the magical complex is simply wishing; the second, perhaps, is expressing the wish in speech. Thus we hear the gardener using strange exclamations, imitative and hortatory, as he plants. First, as he drives his pointed digging-stick into the sodden earth he ejaculates or simply mutters, ‘sigigigigi…!’ with a rapid following on of the syllables which completely baffles the European who tries to imitate. As the same meaningless word is used when the spear sinks into the flank of the pig, it is presumably a sort of onomatope, and meant by the gardener to make easier the sinking of his stick into the ground. When he sometimes says ‘Brrrr …’ it is perhaps with the same vague idea.' [448] 'As he plants the taro he may apostrophize it: O ba erejo, ‘Taro arise!’ by which he means that the leaves should sprout up quickly; or, O ba beji, ‘Taro be hungry!’ i.e. be greedy and take nourishment from the soil; or O ba anumbejo, ‘Taro sit!’ i.e. let the tuber sit comfortably and firmly in the ground. He will also Aja ba, ‘Mother taro!’ by which he may mean that the plant should be prolific and put forth many offsets, or perhaps simply, as some explain it, ‘What a whopper!’ Similarly as he plants sugar-cane he will mutter, ‘Poruporuporu…!’ with the same inimitable rapidity. This is a conventional exclamation and was never explained to me; but as the large bamboo is called Poru, it may well enough have meant originally that the stalks of the sugar-cane should grow up like those of the much larger bamboo which they resemble. Again, as he thrusts the cutting into the ground he may be heard making luscious sucking noises between his teeth, ‘Sip, sip’, and coughing, as if he were already enjoying the sweet juice of the sugar-cane in his own unutterably noisy manner, and half choking himself in his eagerness. In the old life of the Orokaiva there seem to be no large ceremonies in which the direct idea is that of fertility. There is, however, a strong conviction that [Page 148] the spirits of the dead can influence the crops for good or ill. Hence to some extent come the practices of placating the dead with offerings (especially on small platforms, or harau, set up in the actual gardens) and of exhorting the dead man just before burial to depart to a good place where there are pigs in plenty and taro in plenty, whence he may send pigs and taro to his surviving friends. Again, for some reason which remains obscure, the garden of the dead man is tabooed to his immediate friends, though it may be used by others. In general it is felt that the spirits of the dead can prosper the gardens or blast them, and it is worth while using all possible tact to avoid the latter alternative.' [449] 'Whenever things go wrong unexplicably the native is prone to impute his misfortunes to a sorcerer. No doubt sorcery is supposed to be practised a hundred times more often than it is really practised. But there is one rather cunning method which may serve as an example of black magic at work in the garden. When a man finds that a thief has been making free with his taro, sugar-cane, or whatever it may be, he will look about for some remains of the stolen food, and then setting upright in the ground a length of springy stick, he will hold this fragment of food against the upper end, and, bending the stick back, shoot it out of the garden as if by means of a catapult. The effect of this is to make the thief a waster, [Page 150] a neglector of gardens, to drive him away not only from your garden but from his own. The process is called batetekari, ‘throwing away the taro’, and the word is used not only in the literal sense but for other kinds of sorcery.' [450] We are unsure whether these were performed by individuals only or whether family members were present when protective spells were cast. More information on frequent rituals performed prior to the colonial-era expansion of the Taro Cult is needed.
♠ Frequency for the ritual specialist ♣ ♥ Experts should also be able to tell us whether this form of magic was an individual or family affair
♠ Frequency per participant ♣ ♥ Unsure about any textual reference on the frequency per participant, further research needed.
♠ Frequency for the audience ♣ ♥ Unsure about any textual reference on the frequency per audience, further research needed.
♠ Duration ♣ ♥ Unsure about any duration
♠ Typical size of participating group ♣ ♥ in absolute numbers

Most euphoric collective ritual of the official cult[edit]

♠ Name ♣ Raiding Feast ♥ Prior to the colonial period, Orokaiva groups celebrated the return of warriors after successful raids with a feast: 'When the victorious raiders returned they announced their success from afar off by a distinctive rhythm on the hui which (according to Aiga informants) may be represented thus:__ __ _ __, __ __ _ __ __.' [451]//'There were conventional songs proper to the occasion, such as (an Aiga example), Eruga tune kambaja-one Eruga [leaf seasoning] Isuga tune Kambaja-one Isuga [leaf seasoning] by which the women were given to understand that they should prepare ‘cabbage’ for the cooking; or (a Sangara example) Umo tihue kiari-ta koiko-ta, which indicated that the enemy had fled (koiko), anxious to see (kiari) the familiar place where they drew water (umo [Page 172] tihu). The men who had not themselves secured victims would sing (another Sangara example), U sina nane arako, u sina nane, ‘Mine was like a water-fight’, by which they meant that they had fought as ineffectually as children bathing and splashing one another with water.' [452]//'Brought home by the raiders the corpse of the victim was set upright in the village, still attached to its pole. During the night there was dancing to the accompaniment of hui and drum-properly the largest and most old-fashioned of the drums, viz. the ino. In the morning the body was taken down to the stream and cut up in the running water, in order, as I was told, to wash away the blood. Various portions were distributed as they are in the case of a pig, and little odds and ends were given to the children, who played at roasting them in the fires. It was formerly the custom, I understand, to set up skulls of victims on a gaga or small platform in the village, just as pig-jaws are to be seen nowadays ranged along a branch of an old croton scrub. The pig-jaws are mainly in the nature of trophies, though it is said that to throw them away and lose sight of them would have an ill effect on hunting thereafter. I cannot say what were the motives for keeping human skulls, but presumably the same reasons would hold good.' [453]//The slayers and their immediate kin were subject to a set of a taboos: 'The actual slayer abstained from eating any of the victim's body. This rule was rigidly observed, though no satisfactory reason could be given. It may be remarked that the owner of a pig never eats any part of it when it is presented to another at a feast and distributed. But this seems to be no more than a point of etiquette, and perhaps offers no parallel. Beaver, who lays stress on the fact that the slayer must not eat of the slain, adds: ‘Small portions of the liver, ceremonially treated with symbolic herbs, may be bitten into by the actual killer;’ though of this he does not record any explanation. It is tempting to suggest that by this rite the [Page 174] slayer is assimilating some of the courage and fierceness of his victim, though it must be remembered that the liver is regarded as the seat of fear as well as of these more warlike emotions, and, indeed, it is presumably by his very deficiency in these latter that the victim was unable to look after his liver.' [454]//'The tabu on the flesh of the slain applies not only to the slayer but to his father, mother, and nearest relatives. If they were rash enough to partake, their genitalia would swell, their joints grow crooked, and their heads turn bald. (Though in the case of an old man, it was said that these results need not be feared.) In view of such alarming risks it seems likely that there was in the person of the slain something like infection to that of the slayer. Other details confirm this view. The Orokaiva has a lively dread of baupeni (or elephantiasis of the scrotum) and swelling of the joints-both of which afflictions are seen in the Division. The slayer immediately removed his bo, or perineal band, and wore a leaf or nothing until he reached home and could effect a change of clothing: this was a precaution against baupeni. If he had dispatched the victim with a club he would straightway change this for another man's: on no account would he shoulder the club that struck the fatal blow, for he would run a risk of a swollen or distorted shoulder-joint. Again the slayer must perform certain rites and observe certain tabus. He must not drink pure water out of the river, but only that which has been stirred up and made muddy by the feet of a non-slayer. He must not eat taro cooked in the pot, but only that which has been roasted in the open fire. He must abstain from sexual intercourse. These restrictions lasted for a few days and then the slayer ate the same purificatory stew (suna) which is given to initiates at the end of their seclusion (see p. 193). Among the Binandele I witnessed a mock demonstration of a peculiar rite which immediately preceded the eating of the suna. The slayer climbs into a small tree which contains a nest of those large and aggressive insects commonly called ‘green’ ants. The tree should properly be of the kind called Bobo, which [Page 175] is always swarming with them. While he crouches in a fork of the tree, branches are broken and laid over him so that he is almost completely covered and thoroughly bitten. Having endured this for some time, he climbs down and eats the suna, steaming himself over the dish and sponging his joints with handfuls of the stewed leaves. Another rite (also performed at the end of the initiate's seclusion) was to break a coco-nut above the slayer and souse his head with the milk.' [455]//'It seems likely that all these observances and tabus are in a sense not only purificatory but defensive. As a rule, informants have no explanation to offer, but I have been informed directly that they are meant to drive away the asisi, or spirit, of the slain man. In support of this view I may quote what W. N. Beaver has written: ‘I am not disposed to the sole view that the killer is “unclean”. It seems to me rather that rites are necessary to throw off the power of the ghost or ghosts of the slain….’1' [456]//Slayers adopted the names of victims and were entitled to the wearing of special insignia: 'There is a very common practice, already referred to in Chapter VII, which we may be tempted to associate with the same idea. This is the practice of adopting the name of the slain. A man, originally named Koga, for instance, has killed another named Amburi: henceforward he, the slayer, is known by the name of Amburi, the slain. This custom is very common, and has been noted by others, so that it is unnecessary to give a succession of examples. It does not follow that the slayer entirely abandons his original name, which, I am told, may still be used occasionally by his more immediate friends; but his ordinary name is certainly that which he has taken from his victim. When a warrior of distinction has accounted for a number of slain he does not take the name of each in turn, but continues, as a rule, to be known by that of the first. This, however, cannot be an invariable rule, for a certain Ehari of Wasida, who can name no less than seven victims of his own hand, is known by the [Page 176] name of the second. His original name was Ata; his first victim was Asi and his second Ehari. He is now called Ehari though he has since killed five others.' [457]//'There is another kind of distinction, viz. the wearing of certain ornaments, &c., which may be described as homicidal insignia. To these is given the general name otohu, or the specific name of esa. The latter will be found more satisfactory here. The subject of these insignia among the Orokaiva is not so straightforward as we might expect, owing to the fact-a happy one from all points of view save the present-that homicide has long gone out of fashion, or at least no longer bears an honorific implication, so that the customs connected with it cannot be studied directly. The best written on the subject is found in the admirable article by the late W. N. Beaver in the Annual Report, 1918-19, pp. 96-9.' [458]//'The source of confusion is in the fact that otohu ornaments are also given in connexion with initiation, where they certainly do not imply that the recipient has been a man-slayer. The concrete fact that they are given to girls as well as to boys or men is enough to prove this. Beaver [Page 178] made a distinction between homicidal otohu and ‘pig-otohu’, the former being conditioned by the killing of a man, the latter virtually bought with a pig. My own inquiries confirm this distinction, though I would attach more importance to the latter class than he does, and would prefer to state the matter thus, that the esa, or homicidal insignia, are a special class of otohu. The general subject of otohu will be discussed in the next chapter.' [459]//'In the meantime it appears that the man-slayer, having undergone the forms of purification or exorcism, might at some convenient date receive his otohu, or, as I shall call it, qua homicidal insigne, his esa. I say ‘might’ because some of the older informants have assured me that an esa was not given invariably. Moreover, it seems that certain ornaments, which are rightly enough otohu, have been too freely regarded as esa, i.e. as implying that their possessor must be a homicide. My own inquiries have led me to believe that the variety of homicidal insignia was very limited. Beaver has given two lists, one for the coastal and central tribes and one for the Wasida and the trans-Kumusi. The first is of eight, and the second of twelve alternative ornaments or objects. (It will be understood that the River People in the north observe similar customs and use similar esa.) I do not repeat these in full, but draw attention to several of the more striking. It seems likely that Nos. 1 and 2 (the hornbill beaks and the cuscus fur) were exclusive homicidal insignia or esa proper, i.e. they could be worn only by man-slayers. But save for these two, and possibly though doubtfully for the other three mentioned with them, I am led to believe that the long list of ornaments given by Beaver, as well as many others mentioned by native informants, were presented just as readily to the peaceful initiate as to the successful warrior.' [460]//We have provisionally chosen this type of feast as the most euphoric one. The ceremonies performed after the termination of seclusion for initiates are another possible option, but appear to have been more ambiguous in their emotional connotation. This interpretation is open to review.
♠ Frequency for the ritual specialist ♣ suspected unknown ♥
♠ Frequency per participant ♣ suspected unknown ♥ This figure is contingent on the number of raids performed on average. It appears that warfare was frequent in the period immediately prior to colonization [461].
♠ Frequency for the audience ♣ not applicable ♥ This figure is contingent on the number of raids performed on average. It appears that warfare was frequent in the period immediately prior to colonization [462]. Thomas Cressy: As the whole village joined in the celebrations, I coded as 'not applicable'.
♠ Duration ♣ suspected unknown ♥
♠ Typical size of participating group ♣ suspected unknown ♥ in absolute numbers. It appears that the whole village joined in the celebrations [463].
♠ Inclusiveness (ritual specialist) ♣ suspected unknown ♥
♠ Inclusiveness (participants) ♣ whole polity ♥ It appears that the whole village joined in the celebrations [464].
♠ Inclusiveness (audience) ♣ not applicable ♥ It appears that the whole village joined in the celebrations [465]. Thomas Cressy: As the whole village joined in the celebrations, I changed the code from 'whole polity' to 'not applicable'.
Dysphoric elements
♠ fasting ♣ absent ♥ 'Brought home by the raiders the corpse of the victim was set upright in the village, still attached to its pole. During the night there was dancing to the accompaniment of hui and drum-properly the largest and most old-fashioned of the drums, viz. the ino. In the morning the body was taken down to the stream and cut up in the running water, in order, as I was told, to wash away the blood. Various portions were distributed as they are in the case of a pig, and little odds and ends were given to the children, who played at roasting them in the fires.' [466] It is worth noting that there are no records describing how this ritual was performed in the pre-colonial era.
♠ vigil/sleep deprivation ♣ inferred absent ♥ Inferred from the fact that this is not mentioned by sources [467]. However, it is worth noting that there are no records describing how this ritual was performed in the pre-colonial era.

Euphoric elements
♠ feasting ♣ present ♥ 'Brought home by the raiders the corpse of the victim was set upright in the village, still attached to its pole. During the night there was dancing to the accompaniment of hui and drum-properly the largest and most old-fashioned of the drums, viz. the ino. In the morning the body was taken down to the stream and cut up in the running water, in order, as I was told, to wash away the blood. Various portions were distributed as they are in the case of a pig, and little odds and ends were given to the children, who played at roasting them in the fires.' [475] It is worth noting that there are no records describing how this ritual was performed in the pre-colonial era.

♠ dancing ♣ present ♥ 'During the night there was dancing to the accompaniment of hui and drum-properly the largest and most old-fashioned of the drums, viz. the ino.' [479] It is worth noting that there are no records describing how this ritual was performed in the pre-colonial era.
♠ synchronous movement ♣ suspected unknown ♥ 'During the night there was dancing to the accompaniment of hui and drum-properly the largest and most old-fashioned of the drums, viz. the ino.' [480] It is not clear whether this dancing was synchronous.
♠ singing ♣ present ♥ 'There were conventional songs proper to the occasion, such as (an Aiga example), Eruga tune kambaja-one Eruga [leaf seasoning] Isuga tune Kambaja-one Isuga [leaf seasoning] by which the women were given to understand that they should prepare ‘cabbage’ for the cooking; or (a Sangara example) Umo tihue kiari-ta koiko-ta, which indicated that the enemy had fled (koiko), anxious to see (kiari) the familiar place where they drew water (umo [Page 172] tihu). The men who had not themselves secured victims would sing (another Sangara example), U sina nane arako, u sina nane, ‘Mine was like a water-fight’, by which they meant that they had fought as ineffectually as children bathing and splashing one another with water.' [481] It is worth noting that there are no records describing how this ritual was performed in the pre-colonial era.

Though the feast did include the consumption of slain enemies, it is not clear that this counts as a sacrifice, since the enemies were killed in raids.

♠ other ♣ ♥

Most dysphoric collective ritual of the official cult[edit]

♠ Name ♣ Embahi separation ceremony ♥ 'Initiates are brought from the bush into the village. Having entered the village, they form two advancing lines until a large scaffolding is reached, erected at one end of the village. Turning, the men kneel down facing the entrance from which they have come and remain in this position, still keeping silence. It is at this stage that the candidates are presented. Faint cries arise from the bush, becoming louder and louder, and the words “Shi! Shi!” mingled with yells and shrieks are distinguished, and at the same time the candidates are marshalled in, led by their guides. They advance between the lines of men who, hitherto silent, now break up into groups, each catching a lad and running madly up and down the village, followed by the women, waving spears and all uttering cries and yells and rubbing the youngsters' arms, legs, and bodies. They now make a wild rush towards the scaffolding, throwing the lads on it, who endeavour to climb up out of reach, but are torn back by the mob and undergo further agony, until, utterly exhausted with fright and fatigue, they are allowed to climb away. Still retaining their group formation, the men rush forward to the scaffold uttering horrible yells, waving their heads sideways with faces upturned to the lads, and swinging their clubs, only to retreat again. This violence and pandemonium continue through the night. At daybreak the girl candidates are led in and subjected to the same treatment in somewhat milder form. Then the candidates, male and female, are mustered on the ohu platform, where they sit completely covered with hoods of bark-cloth. Trees are pulled down in the village.' [495]
♠ Frequency for the ritual specialist ♣ once per generation ♥ According to variable 'Typical frequency of participation for average participant' in the Ritual Database [496], this ritual occurs 'less often than annually but usually more often than once in a lifetime'. However, this is based on a twentieth-century source [497].
♠ Frequency per participant ♣ once in a lifetime ♥ According to variable 'Typical frequency of participation for average participant' in the Ritual Database [498], this ritual occurs 'once in a lifetime'. However, this is based on a twentieth-century source [499].
♠ Frequency for the audience ♣ once per generation ♥ (Giuseppe Innamorato: Discussed with RAs, unsure about textual reference on the existence of a passive audience, further research needed.). However,the group of initiands is ritually ‘harrassed’ by a group of men from their community. If the other people from the village are passive onlookers who watch the proceedings, they qualify as an audience. Will refer to Ritual Database. According to variable 'Typical frequency of participation for average participant' in the Ritual Database [500], this ritual occurs 'less often than annually but usually more often than once in a lifetime'. However, this is based on a twentieth-century source [501]. Inferred from the fact that both adolescents and adults, men and women, could participate [502]. However, this is based on a twentieth-century source [503].
♠ Duration ♣ 13 ♥ Estimate in hours. According to the 'Ritual duration category' of the Ritual Database [504], this ritual is coded as 'more than 12 hours'. However, this is based on a twentieth-century source [505].
♠ Typical size of participating group ♣ 50 ♥ in absolute numbers. According to the Ritual Database [506], 'Some members of community (<50%) where that is more than 15 persons'. 50 is a very rough estimate. Also, this is based on a twentieth-century source [507].
♠ Inclusiveness (ritual specialist) ♣ majority ♥ Both men and women appear to participate as specialists in this ritual [508]. However, this is based on a twentieth-century source [509].
♠ Inclusiveness (participants) ♣ whole polity ♥ Both adolescents and adults, men and women, participated [510]. However, this is based on a twentieth-century source [511].
♠ Inclusiveness (audience) ♣ whole polity ♥ (Giuseppe Innamorato: Discussed with RAs, unsure about textual reference on the existence of a passive audience, further research needed.). However,the group of initiands is ritually ‘harrassed’ by a group of men from their community. If the other people from the village are passive onlookers who watch the proceedings, they qualify as an audience. Will refer to Ritual Database.
Dysphoric elements
♠ fasting ♣ inferred present ♥ The variable 'fasting' in the Ritual Database [512] is coded as 'present'. However, this is based on a twentieth-century source [513].
♠ vigil/sleep deprivation ♣ inferred present ♥ The variable 'Sleep deprivation' in the Ritual Database [514] is coded as 'present'. However, this is based on a twentieth-century source [515].
♠ fear ♣ inferred present ♥ The variable 'Threats or actions that evince fear' in the Ritual Database [516] is coded as 'present'. However, this is based on a twentieth-century source [517].
♠ humiliation ♣ present ♥ The variable 'Humiliation of participants' in the Ritual Database [518] is coded as 'absent'. However, this is based on a twentieth-century source [519]. Thomas Cressy: The participants, both male and female, are ritually chased, harassed, scared, yelled at by a mob of men. For this reason, I have changed the code to present to reflect this ritual humiliation.
♠ disgust ♣ inferred absent ♥ The variable 'Mention of disgust' in the Ritual Database [520] is coded as 'absent'. However, this is based on a twentieth-century source [521].
♠ poisoning/dysphoria-causing drugs ♣ inferred absent ♥ (e.g. vomiting) 'Vomiting', 'Intake of hallucinogenic drugs', and 'Intake of sedatives' are all coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [522]. However, this is based on a twentieth-century source [523].
♠ pain ♣ inferred present ♥ 'Other' negatively valenced bodily stimulation is coded in the Ritual Database [524] as 'present'. 'Other uncomfortable experience', 'Burning of participants', 'Significant wound or bleeding', and 'Superficial wound' are coded as absent, but 'Whipping/ beating of participants' is coded as present. The average peak dysphoria rating in the Ritual Database [525] is medium-high 4.33. However, this is based on a twentieth-century source [526].
♠ mutilation ♣ inferred absent ♥ 'Burning of participants', 'Significant wound or bleeding', 'Superficial wound', 'Piercing', 'Scarification', 'Tattooing', 'Laceration of sensitive organs (skin, tongue, etc.)', and 'Circumcision/ removal of uvula' are all coded in the Ritual Database [527] as 'absent'. However, this is based on a twentieth-century source [528].
♠ risk of death ♣ inferred absent ♥ Activities that may result in excessive blood loss or deadly infection are coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [529], including 'Significant wound or bleeding', 'Superficial wound', 'Whipping/ beating of participants', 'Piercing', Scarification', 'Tattooing', 'Laceration of sensitive organs (skin, tongue, etc.)', and 'Circumcision/ removal of uvula'. However, this is based on a twentieth-century source [530].
♠ other ♣ present ♥ General rough treatment: 'They advance between the lines of men who, hitherto silent, now break up into groups, each catching a lad and running madly up and down the village, followed by the women, waving spears and all uttering cries and yells and rubbing the youngsters' arms, legs, and bodies. They now make a wild rush towards the scaffolding, throwing the lads on it, who endeavour to climb up out of reach, but are torn back by the mob and undergo further agony, until, utterly exhausted with fright and fatigue, they are allowed to climb away.' [531] However, this is an extract from a twentieth-century source [532].
Euphoric elements
♠ feasting ♣ inferred absent ♥ 'Some participants eat meal together' in the Ritual Database [533] is coded as 'absent'. However, this is based on a twentieth-century source [534].
♠ alcohol ♣ inferred absent ♥ Ritual Database [535] variable 'Intake of alcohol' is coded as 'absent'. However, this is based on a twentieth-century source [536].
♠ euphoria-inducing drugs (other than alcohol) ♣ inferred absent ♥ 'Intake of hallucinogenic drugs', and 'Intake of sedatives' are all coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [537]. However, this is based on a twentieth-century source [538].
♠ sex ♣ inferred absent ♥ 'Sexual intercourse' is coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [539]. However, this is based on a twentieth-century source [540].
♠ dancing ♣ inferred absent ♥ Ritual Database [541] variable 'Dancing or repetitive rhythmic movement' is coded as 'absent'. However, this is based on a twentieth-century source [542].
♠ synchronous movement ♣ inferred present ♥ Ritual Database [543] variable 'Marching/ procession/ Proambulation' is coded as 'present'. However, this is based on a twentieth-century source [544].
♠ singing ♣ inferred absent ♥ Ritual Database [545] variable 'Singing and (repetitive) rhythmic vocalization' is coded as 'absent'. However, this is based on a twentieth-century source [546].
♠ entertainment ♣ inferred absent ♥ Not mentioned by source--which, it should be said, dates to the early twentieth century [547].
♠ other ♣ ♥
Cohesion
♠ honour code ♣ suspected unknown ♥ Difficult to code: initiation rituals often foster some kind of cohesion, but the source [548] provides no useful information in this regard. Also, the source dates to the early twentieth century.
♠ oath taking ♣ inferred absent ♥ 'Narrative or story recounted' is coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [549]'. However, this is based on a twentieth-century source [550].
♠ enemies of any group member are my enemies ♣ suspected unknown ♥ Difficult to code: initiation rituals often foster some kind of cohesion, but the source [551] provides no useful information in this regard. Also, the source dates to the early twentieth century.
♠ willingness to die for each other ♣ suspected unknown ♥ Difficult to code: initiation rituals often foster some kind of cohesion, but the source [552] provides no useful information in this regard. Also, the source dates to the early twentieth century.
♠ obligations to each other's families ♣ suspected unknown ♥ Difficult to code: initiation rituals often foster some kind of cohesion, but the source [553] provides no useful information in this regard. Also, the source dates to the early twentieth century.
♠ other ♣ ♥
♠ Orthopraxy checks ♣ inferred present ♥ Both men and women appear to participate as specialists in this ritual [554]. However, this is based on a twentieth-century source [555]. Presence of ritual specialists.
♠ Orthodoxy checks ♣ inferred present ♥ Both men and women appear to participate as specialists in this ritual [556]. However, this is based on a twentieth-century source [557]. Presence of ritual specialists.
Costs of participation
♠ currency ♣ absent ♥ No formal currency is present.
♠ property/valuable items ♣ inferred absent ♥ Not mentioned by source--which, it should be said, dates to the early twentieth century [558].
♠ health costs ♣ present ♥ Participants are whipped and beaten. However, this is based on a twentieth-century source [559].
♠ animal sacrifice ♣ inferred absent ♥ 'Sacrifice of animals' is coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [560]. However, this is based on a twentieth-century source [561].
♠ human sacrifice of an out-group member ♣ inferred absent ♥ 'Sacrifice of humans' is coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [562]. However, this is based on a twentieth-century source [563].
♠ human sacrifice of an in-group member ♣ inferred absent ♥ 'Sacrifice of humans' is coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [564]. However, this is based on a twentieth-century source [565].
♠ human sacrifice of a relative ♣ inferred absent ♥ 'Sacrifice of humans' is coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [566]. However, this is based on a twentieth-century source [567].
♠ other ♣ ♥

Phase II Variables (polity-based)[edit]

Institutional Variables[edit]

♠ RA ♣ Eva Brandl ♥

♠ Expert ♣ ♥

♠ Editor ♣ ♥

Note: Political authority was confined to the informal leadership of elders and local big men: 'Political organization incorporates no central authority or hereditary leadership. Instead, it is characterized by big-men(EMBO DAMBO) and an ascendancy of elders who have proved themselves equal to the task. Such men command the respect of the village, based upon observed qualities of generosity, diligence, wealth, ability to make wise decisions, and skill in arranging ceremonial activities. This status confers no sanctioning authority, however. The Orokaiva tribes, around twelve in number, are very loose units politically and recognize no single leader. The largest unit is the tribe, which has a common territory usually demarcated from neighboring tribal territories by a belt of uninhabited land.' [568] The labour and support of wives and younger men was key in the career of big men: 'Without multiple wives or a pool of single men retainers, the scope for a leader in large-scale exchange is limited. The lack of retainers attaching themselves to leaders' households could perhaps be due to the end of warfare and to improved community health so that there are now few orphans or fatherless sons. Almost every youth has a father or older brother to guarantee the payment of his brideprice. The productive relations between old men and young men are interesting in that they provide the possibility for a form of exploitation or unequal return for equal work, with the old men withholding the young men's access to a bride.' [569] 'The social system is characterized by flexibility in arrangements for group membership and for transmission of rights to land. A village normally contains more than one clan branch and consequently is not necessarily a landholding unit. Residents may have closer kinship ties to residents of other villages than with some of their coresidents. Nevertheless, common residence implies some community of interest and a degree of group solidarity that is reinforced by government policy, which recognizes villages rather than descent groups as functional entities. Marriages between members of different clan branches within the village also reinforce this solidarity, which is expressed in ways such as daily food gifts, cooperation in certain tasks, and joint ceremonial activities. On the average, a lineage comprises three households. Usually, several clans are represented in a village, with members of a single clan (clan branches) being scattered among a number of neighboring villages. Lineages are more localized in cha racter, frequently being confined to a single village and tending to occupy one section of it.' [570] 'There were ordinarily no persons who could command the allegiance of the tribe as a whole, nor was there any status with authority to effect the settlement of disputes between different subgroups or their individual members. Sometimes persistent intratribal conflicts led to short-term migration or to a splinter-group's secession from the tribe. However, these disturbances were very minor in comparison with the ‘flight, dispersal and migration’ in general resulting from incessant intertribal feuds (see p. 35).' [571] According to Williams, village and clan clusters occasionally formed ad hoc alliances when facing external threats: 'Williams ascribes the formation of ‘somewhat loose’ and temporary ‘confederacies of clans’, which conducted raids upon the tribe's kitoho, to a local spirit. But it is not clear whether by this he means the identification of members of a tribe with one territory or the unity of the ‘locality group’ which usually takes in a number of ‘clan-village units’ (see p.34) and which he describes as a more restricted ‘sympathy-group’ than the tribe (1930:107, 157, 163, 309-12). When he states (1925:407) that ‘over and above clan patriarchs there are recognised leaders of small clan confederacies and even - in war-time - of tribes’, he seems to equate the tribe with the district among the mountain Orokaiva (in particular Wasida and Isivita; see W.23, 124).' [572] 'This combination for better defence may have been characteristic of tribes throughout the Orokaiva area. We believe, however, that the subdividing of the tribe into discrete named groups of named villages (either district or ‘hamlet group’) would be unique to the mountain Orokaiva in the culture area; we do not have enough evidence to show if this feature is related to the earlier clustering for safety, and to the greater population density in this tribe.' [573] Accordingly, some of the below variables might not apply to the Orokaiva.

Limits on Power of the Chief Executive[edit]

Legal (formal) limits[edit]

♠ Executive power is separate or independent from military ♣ absent ♥ The Orokaiva did not employ professional military officers in interclan warfare, relying on residential and kin ties as well as informal leadership: 'In interclan warfare, the Binandere organised a division of fighting labour. The first group, the scouts, were sent ahead to kill the scouts of the enemy's main body. Then there were the front-line fighters, experienced men armed with clubs/spears and shields, forming the vanguard. Then there was a group of young people and men who had not killed. They beat drums, blew conch shells, sang war songs and generally used sound to frighten the enemy. Full-scale tribal warfare required the addition of two more groups. Firstly, sorcerers were carried on roofed litters from which they attempted to ward off enemy spirits. Being ritually pure they could have no contact with water. They ate only baked taro or bananas with coconut juice as well as much ginger. The second additional group were the strategists who were vital for long-drawn-out battles. This small group planned tactics, directed the front line and organised ambush killings and so on (1972:13-25).' [574] 'Kinship and local affiliation together were the basic principles by which subgroups of the raiding party seem to have been drawn up during attack and on which leaders within the party based their rights to command specific combatants.' [575] 'Waiko (1972) describes in detail the warfare of the Binandere, a society which like the ancient Spartans was reputed to practise infanticide on weak or deformed sons (Monckton 1922:130). Training for warfare began at an early age for boys. At about 12 years old they began living together in a men's house and learning to dodge spears and to hold shields. Eventually they were required to prove themselves by killing a person in a raid (Waiko 1972:21). Part of the education imparted to the youths in the house was their primary duty to take revenge for the death of a clan member. A clan victim represented the clan and failure to avenge his death badly weakened their prestige and status. Killings had up to two generations delayed payback (1972:24-5).' [576] There was no institutional separation between executive and military leadership as authority was informal and Big Men could act as war-leaders on an ad hoc basis.
♠ Executive power is separate or independent from legislative ♣ absent ♥ There was no separate legislative body. Communities relied on the informal leadership of elders and Big Men (see also above).
♠ Executive power is separate or independent from judiciary ♣ absent ♥ SCCS variable 149 'Writing and Records' is coded as ‘1’ or ‘None’, not ‘Mnemonic devices’, or ‘Nonwritten records’, or 'True writing, no records', or ‘True writing; records’. SCCS variable 89 'Judiciary' is coded as ‘1’ or 'absent'. Local law was informal: 'There is a word igege (Binandele yege) which may be translated ‘moral law’, or perhaps, since the examples are all negative, ‘moral prohibition’. The examples were such as the following: not to steal a man's vegetables, canoes, spears, &c.; not to usurp his fishing rights; not to take his dog to hunt, but to drive it back if it followed the hunter of its own accord; not to commit adultery; not to beat one's wife overmuch; not to commit assault on another man. These igege were for adults; they did not apply to children, who had to be treated with so much indulgence; still less to dogs, whose nature it was to steal on sight. While not implying standardization, the mere existence of the word hints at a definite conception of right and wrong.' [577] So was judicial procedure on the village level: 'For those who remain in the village, the sanctioning mechanisms are mostly informal. Failure in one's obligations means loss of status, leads to gossip, derogatory remarks to one's face, perhaps even a harangue at night by a man at the other end in the village. The councillor, the court and the police are only a last resort in serious quarrels. I saw a councillor enter a dispute once, playing a mediating role between disputants from two villages, but without playing more than an advisory role. One quarrel was taken to court, but this was not a case where traditional mechanisms of social control had failed. A woman accused her husband of adultery with one of the new Garombi arrivals. She and the husband fought and had to be separated as the lady had an axe; the domestic dispute soon died down but the Garombi woman laid a complaint for slander with the police. Before this came to court, the wife had been roundly condemned by almost everyone in the village; she had repented, had gone round the village to signify her regrets, and been as contrite as her pride could possibly allow her to be. The court let her off with a reprimand. The episode, far from suggesting a flagging of Orokaiva traditional social control, had demonstrated to me that it was still effective. Nonetheless, the Orokaiva, as so many other peoples in contact with Western civilisation, have been quick to see the advantages of a judicial system providing an impartial arbiter in disputes, to whose decisions both parties will defer. At the moment, this western judicial system is an additional resource of Orokaiva law, without undermining its existing institutions.' [578] 'There is no judicial procedure among the Orokaiva, and no ‘police force’. In so far as sorcery is concerned, by the way, these deficiencies are perhaps not altogether deplorable. The suspicion of sorcery, where it is backed up by ignorant legal authority, may go to extraordinary lengths of oppression. No Papuan people has reached that stage of legal development which would have made possible such condemnations as those of West Africa' [579] No native courts were present: 'It will be seen, from what I have said, that this book offers a many-sided attraction, but to an administrator the most interesting part is the last chapter. For in that chapter Mr. Williams deals with a phenomenon which has always appeared to me to be very difficult to understand, though it is common enough in Papua, and that is the well-ordered regulation of a peaceful society with apparently no government and no administration of justice to support it. There are no chiefs with any authority worth talking about among the Orokaiva, and the same is true of nearly the whole of Papua, and there are no Courts and no recognized method of enforcing native law or custom, and yet within the community, within what Mr. Williams calls the ‘sympathy group’, life is probably as peaceful and as orderly as it is with us. How this result can be obtained in the absence of any objective sanction is one of the puzzles of native administration.' [580] Accordingly, we cannot speak of a formal separation between executive and judicial institutions.

Legal (formal) freedoms[edit]

♠ Right to petition executive ♣ ♥
♠ Critique of executive by government ♣ ♥
♠ Critique of executive by non-government ♣ ♥

Power distributed[edit]

♠ Sanction of executive by government ♣ ♥
♠ Sanction of executive by non-government ♣ ♥
♠ Constraint on executive by government ♣ ♥
♠ Constraint on executive by non-government ♣ ♥
♠ Impeachment ♣ ♥

Customary (informal) checks on executive[edit]

♠ Informal critique of executive ♣ ♥
♠ Informal sanction of executive ♣ ♥
♠ Informal constraint on executive ♣ ♥
♠ Informal impeachment ♣ ♥

Limits on executive power imposed by religious agents[edit]

♠ Critique of executive by religious agents ♣ ♥
♠ Sanction of executive by religious agents ♣ ♥
♠ Constraint on executive by religious agents ♣ ♥
♠ Constraint on executive by religious institutions ♣ ♥
♠ Impeachment by religious agents ♣ ♥
♠ Subordination of the chief executive to a religious agent ♣ ♥
♠ Motivation by belief in supernatural agent ♣ ♥

Mechanisms of Power Transfer (from one head of state to the next)[edit]

♠ Customary mechanism ♣ absent ♥ Power transfers were informal. Hereditary succession was only practiced in öarger clans: 'The Orokaiva clan is virtually a patriarchal group; there is no real chieftainship, but a recognized ascendancy of the old man, provided his vigour of mind and body is equal to his position. As it begins to fail his place is gradually occupied by a younger man. Only in the larger clans, where there are well-defined family groups, does the question of hereditary succession appear, and then it is a somewhat faint appearance.' [581] Accordingly, we have decided to code 'absent'. This is open to review.
♠ Legal mechanism ♣ absent ♥ See above.
♠ Number of power transitions ♣ ♥
♠ Number of contested transitions ♣ ♥
♠ Number of successful overturns ♣ ♥

Central Bureaucracy[edit]

♠ State-level administrators ♣ absent ♥ Social control was informal. Note: Political authority was confined to the informal leadership of elders and local big men: 'Political organization incorporates no central authority or hereditary leadership. Instead, it is characterized by big-men(EMBO DAMBO) and an ascendancy of elders who have proved themselves equal to the task. Such men command the respect of the village, based upon observed qualities of generosity, diligence, wealth, ability to make wise decisions, and skill in arranging ceremonial activities. This status confers no sanctioning authority, however. The Orokaiva tribes, around twelve in number, are very loose units politically and recognize no single leader. The largest unit is the tribe, which has a common territory usually demarcated from neighboring tribal territories by a belt of uninhabited land.' [582] The labour and support of wives and younger men was key in the career of big men: 'Without multiple wives or a pool of single men retainers, the scope for a leader in large-scale exchange is limited. The lack of retainers attaching themselves to leaders' households could perhaps be due to the end of warfare and to improved community health so that there are now few orphans or fatherless sons. Almost every youth has a father or older brother to guarantee the payment of his brideprice. The productive relations between old men and young men are interesting in that they provide the possibility for a form of exploitation or unequal return for equal work, with the old men withholding the young men's access to a bride.' [583] 'The social system is characterized by flexibility in arrangements for group membership and for transmission of rights to land. A village normally contains more than one clan branch and consequently is not necessarily a landholding unit. Residents may have closer kinship ties to residents of other villages than with some of their coresidents. Nevertheless, common residence implies some community of interest and a degree of group solidarity that is reinforced by government policy, which recognizes villages rather than descent groups as functional entities. Marriages between members of different clan branches within the village also reinforce this solidarity, which is expressed in ways such as daily food gifts, cooperation in certain tasks, and joint ceremonial activities. On the average, a lineage comprises three households. Usually, several clans are represented in a village, with members of a single clan (clan branches) being scattered among a number of neighboring villages. Lineages are more localized in cha racter, frequently being confined to a single village and tending to occupy one section of it.' [584] 'There were ordinarily no persons who could command the allegiance of the tribe as a whole, nor was there any status with authority to effect the settlement of disputes between different subgroups or their individual members. Sometimes persistent intratribal conflicts led to short-term migration or to a splinter-group's secession from the tribe. However, these disturbances were very minor in comparison with the ‘flight, dispersal and migration’ in general resulting from incessant intertribal feuds (see p. 35).' [585] According to Williams, village and clan clusters occasionally formed ad hoc alliances when facing external threats: 'Williams ascribes the formation of ‘somewhat loose’ and temporary ‘confederacies of clans’, which conducted raids upon the tribe's kitoho, to a local spirit. But it is not clear whether by this he means the identification of members of a tribe with one territory or the unity of the ‘locality group’ which usually takes in a number of ‘clan-village units’ (see p.34) and which he describes as a more restricted ‘sympathy-group’ than the tribe (1930:107, 157, 163, 309-12). When he states (1925:407) that ‘over and above clan patriarchs there are recognised leaders of small clan confederacies and even - in war-time - of tribes’, he seems to equate the tribe with the district among the mountain Orokaiva (in particular Wasida and Isivita; see W.23, 124).' [586] 'This combination for better defence may have been characteristic of tribes throughout the Orokaiva area. We believe, however, that the subdividing of the tribe into discrete named groups of named villages (either district or ‘hamlet group’) would be unique to the mountain Orokaiva in the culture area; we do not have enough evidence to show if this feature is related to the earlier clustering for safety, and to the greater population density in this tribe.' [587] Accordingly, the below variables might not apply to the Orokaiva.

♠ Prestige of state-level bureaucracy ♣ ♥

Local-level officials (provincial, regional, civic administration)[edit]

♠ Number of regional administrative units ♣ ♥

♠ Local-level administrators ♣ absent ♥ Social control was informal. Note: Political authority was confined to the informal leadership of elders and local big men: 'Political organization incorporates no central authority or hereditary leadership. Instead, it is characterized by big-men(EMBO DAMBO) and an ascendancy of elders who have proved themselves equal to the task. Such men command the respect of the village, based upon observed qualities of generosity, diligence, wealth, ability to make wise decisions, and skill in arranging ceremonial activities. This status confers no sanctioning authority, however. The Orokaiva tribes, around twelve in number, are very loose units politically and recognize no single leader.
