In the fable where a crocodile devours a man, his wife goes into seclusion immediately; but when on the following day her son captures the crocodile and drags it to the house, she comes down, stands on the creature's body, and cries, ‘Why did you take my man?’; and then the people dance the kuru dance, and her seclusion is over.' [879] 'In peaceful modern times the victims would be unprocurable, and by the same token the necessity for them does not arise. The seclusion, therefore, is brought to an end when there is a suitable accumulation of food, and its duration is correspondingly variable. The feast on this occasion is called pusu-ijuka, lit. ‘the counting of the mud’, i.e. the reckoning by which the pusu-embo (p. 211) are paid for their efforts at the funeral. The people of the deceased husband provide the bulk of the provisions for this feast, but they are assisted by the people of the widow. All the mourners who paid the deceased the final compliment of bedaubing themselves with mud, of wailing, or of digging his grave, are invited to receive their ‘payment’; but relatives on both husband's and wife's side will contribute. Apart, however, [Page [p. 218A]] PLATE XXIX [Page 219] from this paying of the nondescript body of mourners to which both groups contribute, it is evident that on the occasion of the gorukari the people of the deceased husband make some payment of food to those of the widow. In fact, amid some confusion of evidence it appears that it is virtually the people of the deceased husband who provide the feast which makes it possible for the widow to emerge from seclusion.' [880] 'Sacrifice of humans' is coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database for all logged Orokaiva rituals. [881]. However, this is based on a twentieth-century source [882].

♠ human sacrifice of an out-group member ♣ inferred absent ♥ Inferred absent. The only reference that could be understood as Human Sacrifice is the consumption of enemies, but it is a borderline case as it doesn't seem to be directly connected to appeasing supernatural agents. Ask expert. 'The widow's seclusion comes to an end with a feast and a ceremony called gorukari. This, it will be remembered, marks the second stage in the cycle of mortuary ceremonies (vide p. 210).' [883] 'When, in former times, the widow's husband had been slain by an enemy tribe, her seclusion must continue till a victim had been secured from that tribe; and it was the corpse of this victim which constituted the pièce de résistance of the feast. She was compelled to remain in seclusion till revenge was satisfied. In the fable where a crocodile devours a man, his wife goes into seclusion immediately; but when on the following day her son captures the crocodile and drags it to the house, she comes down, stands on the creature's body, and cries, ‘Why did you take my man?’; and then the people dance the kuru dance, and her seclusion is over.' [884] 'In peaceful modern times the victims would be unprocurable, and by the same token the necessity for them does not arise. The seclusion, therefore, is brought to an end when there is a suitable accumulation of food, and its duration is correspondingly variable. The feast on this occasion is called pusu-ijuka, lit. ‘the counting of the mud’, i.e. the reckoning by which the pusu-embo (p. 211) are paid for their efforts at the funeral. The people of the deceased husband provide the bulk of the provisions for this feast, but they are assisted by the people of the widow. All the mourners who paid the deceased the final compliment of bedaubing themselves with mud, of wailing, or of digging his grave, are invited to receive their ‘payment’; but relatives on both husband's and wife's side will contribute. Apart, however, [Page [p. 218A]] PLATE XXIX [Page 219] from this paying of the nondescript body of mourners to which both groups contribute, it is evident that on the occasion of the gorukari the people of the deceased husband make some payment of food to those of the widow. In fact, amid some confusion of evidence it appears that it is virtually the people of the deceased husband who provide the feast which makes it possible for the widow to emerge from seclusion.' [885] 'Sacrifice of humans' is coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database for all logged Orokaiva rituals. [886]. However, this is based on a twentieth-century source [887].
♠ human sacrifice of an in-group member ♣ inferred absent ♥ Inferred absent. The only reference that could be understood as Human Sacrifice is the consumption of enemies, but it is a borderline case as it doesn't seem to be directly connected to appeasing supernatural agents. Ask expert. 'The widow's seclusion comes to an end with a feast and a ceremony called gorukari. This, it will be remembered, marks the second stage in the cycle of mortuary ceremonies (vide p. 210).' [888] 'When, in former times, the widow's husband had been slain by an enemy tribe, her seclusion must continue till a victim had been secured from that tribe; and it was the corpse of this victim which constituted the pièce de résistance of the feast. She was compelled to remain in seclusion till revenge was satisfied. In the fable where a crocodile devours a man, his wife goes into seclusion immediately; but when on the following day her son captures the crocodile and drags it to the house, she comes down, stands on the creature's body, and cries, ‘Why did you take my man?’; and then the people dance the kuru dance, and her seclusion is over.' [889] 'In peaceful modern times the victims would be unprocurable, and by the same token the necessity for them does not arise. The seclusion, therefore, is brought to an end when there is a suitable accumulation of food, and its duration is correspondingly variable. The feast on this occasion is called pusu-ijuka, lit. ‘the counting of the mud’, i.e. the reckoning by which the pusu-embo (p. 211) are paid for their efforts at the funeral. The people of the deceased husband provide the bulk of the provisions for this feast, but they are assisted by the people of the widow. All the mourners who paid the deceased the final compliment of bedaubing themselves with mud, of wailing, or of digging his grave, are invited to receive their ‘payment’; but relatives on both husband's and wife's side will contribute. Apart, however, [Page [p. 218A]] PLATE XXIX [Page 219] from this paying of the nondescript body of mourners to which both groups contribute, it is evident that on the occasion of the gorukari the people of the deceased husband make some payment of food to those of the widow. In fact, amid some confusion of evidence it appears that it is virtually the people of the deceased husband who provide the feast which makes it possible for the widow to emerge from seclusion.' [890] 'Sacrifice of humans' is coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database for all logged Orokaiva rituals. [891]. However, this is based on a twentieth-century source [892].
♠ human sacrifice of a low-status individual ♣ inferred absent ♥ Inferred absent. The only reference that could be understood as Human Sacrifice is the consumption of enemies, but it is a borderline case as it doesn't seem to be directly connected to appeasing supernatural agents. Ask expert. 'The widow's seclusion comes to an end with a feast and a ceremony called gorukari. This, it will be remembered, marks the second stage in the cycle of mortuary ceremonies (vide p. 210).' [893] 'When, in former times, the widow's husband had been slain by an enemy tribe, her seclusion must continue till a victim had been secured from that tribe; and it was the corpse of this victim which constituted the pièce de résistance of the feast. She was compelled to remain in seclusion till revenge was satisfied. In the fable where a crocodile devours a man, his wife goes into seclusion immediately; but when on the following day her son captures the crocodile and drags it to the house, she comes down, stands on the creature's body, and cries, ‘Why did you take my man?’; and then the people dance the kuru dance, and her seclusion is over.' [894] 'In peaceful modern times the victims would be unprocurable, and by the same token the necessity for them does not arise. The seclusion, therefore, is brought to an end when there is a suitable accumulation of food, and its duration is correspondingly variable. The feast on this occasion is called pusu-ijuka, lit. ‘the counting of the mud’, i.e. the reckoning by which the pusu-embo (p. 211) are paid for their efforts at the funeral. The people of the deceased husband provide the bulk of the provisions for this feast, but they are assisted by the people of the widow. All the mourners who paid the deceased the final compliment of bedaubing themselves with mud, of wailing, or of digging his grave, are invited to receive their ‘payment’; but relatives on both husband's and wife's side will contribute. Apart, however, [Page [p. 218A]] PLATE XXIX [Page 219] from this paying of the nondescript body of mourners to which both groups contribute, it is evident that on the occasion of the gorukari the people of the deceased husband make some payment of food to those of the widow. In fact, amid some confusion of evidence it appears that it is virtually the people of the deceased husband who provide the feast which makes it possible for the widow to emerge from seclusion.' [895] 'Sacrifice of humans' is coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database for all logged Orokaiva rituals. [896]. However, this is based on a twentieth-century source [897].
♠ human sacrifice of a criminal ♣ inferred absent ♥ Inferred absent. The only reference that could be understood as Human Sacrifice is the consumption of enemies, but it is a borderline case as it doesn't seem to be directly connected to appeasing supernatural agents. Ask expert. 'The widow's seclusion comes to an end with a feast and a ceremony called gorukari. This, it will be remembered, marks the second stage in the cycle of mortuary ceremonies (vide p. 210).' [898] 'When, in former times, the widow's husband had been slain by an enemy tribe, her seclusion must continue till a victim had been secured from that tribe; and it was the corpse of this victim which constituted the pièce de résistance of the feast. She was compelled to remain in seclusion till revenge was satisfied. In the fable where a crocodile devours a man, his wife goes into seclusion immediately; but when on the following day her son captures the crocodile and drags it to the house, she comes down, stands on the creature's body, and cries, ‘Why did you take my man?’; and then the people dance the kuru dance, and her seclusion is over.' [899] 'In peaceful modern times the victims would be unprocurable, and by the same token the necessity for them does not arise. The seclusion, therefore, is brought to an end when there is a suitable accumulation of food, and its duration is correspondingly variable. The feast on this occasion is called pusu-ijuka, lit. ‘the counting of the mud’, i.e. the reckoning by which the pusu-embo (p. 211) are paid for their efforts at the funeral. The people of the deceased husband provide the bulk of the provisions for this feast, but they are assisted by the people of the widow. All the mourners who paid the deceased the final compliment of bedaubing themselves with mud, of wailing, or of digging his grave, are invited to receive their ‘payment’; but relatives on both husband's and wife's side will contribute. Apart, however, [Page [p. 218A]] PLATE XXIX [Page 219] from this paying of the nondescript body of mourners to which both groups contribute, it is evident that on the occasion of the gorukari the people of the deceased husband make some payment of food to those of the widow. In fact, amid some confusion of evidence it appears that it is virtually the people of the deceased husband who provide the feast which makes it possible for the widow to emerge from seclusion.' [900] 'Sacrifice of humans' is coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database for all logged Orokaiva rituals. [901]. However, this is based on a twentieth-century source [902].
♠ human sacrifice of a high status individual ♣ inferred absent ♥ Inferred absent. The only reference that could be understood as Human Sacrifice is the consumption of enemies, but it is a borderline case as it doesn't seem to be directly connected to appeasing supernatural agents. Ask expert. 'The widow's seclusion comes to an end with a feast and a ceremony called gorukari. This, it will be remembered, marks the second stage in the cycle of mortuary ceremonies (vide p. 210).' [903] 'When, in former times, the widow's husband had been slain by an enemy tribe, her seclusion must continue till a victim had been secured from that tribe; and it was the corpse of this victim which constituted the pièce de résistance of the feast. She was compelled to remain in seclusion till revenge was satisfied. In the fable where a crocodile devours a man, his wife goes into seclusion immediately; but when on the following day her son captures the crocodile and drags it to the house, she comes down, stands on the creature's body, and cries, ‘Why did you take my man?’; and then the people dance the kuru dance, and her seclusion is over.' [904] 'In peaceful modern times the victims would be unprocurable, and by the same token the necessity for them does not arise. The seclusion, therefore, is brought to an end when there is a suitable accumulation of food, and its duration is correspondingly variable. The feast on this occasion is called pusu-ijuka, lit. ‘the counting of the mud’, i.e. the reckoning by which the pusu-embo (p. 211) are paid for their efforts at the funeral. The people of the deceased husband provide the bulk of the provisions for this feast, but they are assisted by the people of the widow. All the mourners who paid the deceased the final compliment of bedaubing themselves with mud, of wailing, or of digging his grave, are invited to receive their ‘payment’; but relatives on both husband's and wife's side will contribute. Apart, however, [Page [p. 218A]] PLATE XXIX [Page 219] from this paying of the nondescript body of mourners to which both groups contribute, it is evident that on the occasion of the gorukari the people of the deceased husband make some payment of food to those of the widow. In fact, amid some confusion of evidence it appears that it is virtually the people of the deceased husband who provide the feast which makes it possible for the widow to emerge from seclusion.' [905] 'Sacrifice of humans' is coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database for all logged Orokaiva rituals. [906]. However, this is based on a twentieth-century source [907].
♠ human sacrifice of a relative ♣ inferred absent ♥ Inferred absent. The only reference that could be understood as Human Sacrifice is the consumption of enemies, but it is a borderline case as it doesn't seem to be directly connected to appeasing supernatural agents. Ask expert. 'The widow's seclusion comes to an end with a feast and a ceremony called gorukari. This, it will be remembered, marks the second stage in the cycle of mortuary ceremonies (vide p. 210).' [908] 'When, in former times, the widow's husband had been slain by an enemy tribe, her seclusion must continue till a victim had been secured from that tribe; and it was the corpse of this victim which constituted the pièce de résistance of the feast. She was compelled to remain in seclusion till revenge was satisfied. In the fable where a crocodile devours a man, his wife goes into seclusion immediately; but when on the following day her son captures the crocodile and drags it to the house, she comes down, stands on the creature's body, and cries, ‘Why did you take my man?’; and then the people dance the kuru dance, and her seclusion is over.' [909] 'In peaceful modern times the victims would be unprocurable, and by the same token the necessity for them does not arise. The seclusion, therefore, is brought to an end when there is a suitable accumulation of food, and its duration is correspondingly variable. The feast on this occasion is called pusu-ijuka, lit. ‘the counting of the mud’, i.e. the reckoning by which the pusu-embo (p. 211) are paid for their efforts at the funeral. The people of the deceased husband provide the bulk of the provisions for this feast, but they are assisted by the people of the widow. All the mourners who paid the deceased the final compliment of bedaubing themselves with mud, of wailing, or of digging his grave, are invited to receive their ‘payment’; but relatives on both husband's and wife's side will contribute. Apart, however, [Page [p. 218A]] PLATE XXIX [Page 219] from this paying of the nondescript body of mourners to which both groups contribute, it is evident that on the occasion of the gorukari the people of the deceased husband make some payment of food to those of the widow. In fact, amid some confusion of evidence it appears that it is virtually the people of the deceased husband who provide the feast which makes it possible for the widow to emerge from seclusion.' [910] 'Sacrifice of humans' is coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database for all logged Orokaiva rituals. [911]. However, this is based on a twentieth-century source [912].
♠ human sacrifice of other ♣ ♥
♠ Maximum known number of victims in a HS event ♣ 0 ♥ Inferred absent. The only reference that could be understood as Human Sacrifice is the consumption of enemies, but it is a borderline case as it doesn't seem to be directly connected to appeasing supernatural agents. Ask expert. 'The widow's seclusion comes to an end with a feast and a ceremony called gorukari. This, it will be remembered, marks the second stage in the cycle of mortuary ceremonies (vide p. 210).' [913] 'When, in former times, the widow's husband had been slain by an enemy tribe, her seclusion must continue till a victim had been secured from that tribe; and it was the corpse of this victim which constituted the pièce de résistance of the feast. She was compelled to remain in seclusion till revenge was satisfied. In the fable where a crocodile devours a man, his wife goes into seclusion immediately; but when on the following day her son captures the crocodile and drags it to the house, she comes down, stands on the creature's body, and cries, ‘Why did you take my man?’; and then the people dance the kuru dance, and her seclusion is over.' [914] 'In peaceful modern times the victims would be unprocurable, and by the same token the necessity for them does not arise. The seclusion, therefore, is brought to an end when there is a suitable accumulation of food, and its duration is correspondingly variable. The feast on this occasion is called pusu-ijuka, lit. ‘the counting of the mud’, i.e. the reckoning by which the pusu-embo (p. 211) are paid for their efforts at the funeral. The people of the deceased husband provide the bulk of the provisions for this feast, but they are assisted by the people of the widow. All the mourners who paid the deceased the final compliment of bedaubing themselves with mud, of wailing, or of digging his grave, are invited to receive their ‘payment’; but relatives on both husband's and wife's side will contribute. Apart, however, [Page [p. 218A]] PLATE XXIX [Page 219] from this paying of the nondescript body of mourners to which both groups contribute, it is evident that on the occasion of the gorukari the people of the deceased husband make some payment of food to those of the widow. In fact, amid some confusion of evidence it appears that it is virtually the people of the deceased husband who provide the feast which makes it possible for the widow to emerge from seclusion.' [915] 'Sacrifice of humans' is coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database for all logged Orokaiva rituals. [916]. However, this is based on a twentieth-century source [917].
♠ Capital Punishment for Religious Offenses ♣ ♥
♠ Capital Punishment for Witchcraft ♣ ♥
♠ Influential figure forbids human sacrifice for in-group member ♣ suspected unknown ♥
♠ Influential figure forbids human sacrifice universally ♣ suspected unknown ♥
♠ Official cult forbids human sacrifice for in-group member ♣ unknown ♥ Inferred absent. The only reference that could be understood as Human Sacrifice is the consumption of enemies, but it is a borderline case as it doesn't seem to be directly connected to appeasing supernatural agents. Ask expert. 'The widow's seclusion comes to an end with a feast and a ceremony called gorukari. This, it will be remembered, marks the second stage in the cycle of mortuary ceremonies (vide p. 210).' [918] 'When, in former times, the widow's husband had been slain by an enemy tribe, her seclusion must continue till a victim had been secured from that tribe; and it was the corpse of this victim which constituted the pièce de résistance of the feast. She was compelled to remain in seclusion till revenge was satisfied. In the fable where a crocodile devours a man, his wife goes into seclusion immediately; but when on the following day her son captures the crocodile and drags it to the house, she comes down, stands on the creature's body, and cries, ‘Why did you take my man?’; and then the people dance the kuru dance, and her seclusion is over.' [919] 'In peaceful modern times the victims would be unprocurable, and by the same token the necessity for them does not arise. The seclusion, therefore, is brought to an end when there is a suitable accumulation of food, and its duration is correspondingly variable. The feast on this occasion is called pusu-ijuka, lit. ‘the counting of the mud’, i.e. the reckoning by which the pusu-embo (p. 211) are paid for their efforts at the funeral. The people of the deceased husband provide the bulk of the provisions for this feast, but they are assisted by the people of the widow. All the mourners who paid the deceased the final compliment of bedaubing themselves with mud, of wailing, or of digging his grave, are invited to receive their ‘payment’; but relatives on both husband's and wife's side will contribute. Apart, however, [Page [p. 218A]] PLATE XXIX [Page 219] from this paying of the nondescript body of mourners to which both groups contribute, it is evident that on the occasion of the gorukari the people of the deceased husband make some payment of food to those of the widow. In fact, amid some confusion of evidence it appears that it is virtually the people of the deceased husband who provide the feast which makes it possible for the widow to emerge from seclusion.' [920] 'Sacrifice of humans' is coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database for all logged Orokaiva rituals. [921]. However, this is based on a twentieth-century source [922].
♠ Official cult forbids human sacrifice universally ♣ unknown ♥ Inferred absent. The only reference that could be understood as Human Sacrifice is the consumption of enemies, but it is a borderline case as it doesn't seem to be directly connected to appeasing supernatural agents. Ask expert. 'The widow's seclusion comes to an end with a feast and a ceremony called gorukari. This, it will be remembered, marks the second stage in the cycle of mortuary ceremonies (vide p. 210).' [923] 'When, in former times, the widow's husband had been slain by an enemy tribe, her seclusion must continue till a victim had been secured from that tribe; and it was the corpse of this victim which constituted the pièce de résistance of the feast. She was compelled to remain in seclusion till revenge was satisfied. In the fable where a crocodile devours a man, his wife goes into seclusion immediately; but when on the following day her son captures the crocodile and drags it to the house, she comes down, stands on the creature's body, and cries, ‘Why did you take my man?’; and then the people dance the kuru dance, and her seclusion is over.' [924] 'In peaceful modern times the victims would be unprocurable, and by the same token the necessity for them does not arise. The seclusion, therefore, is brought to an end when there is a suitable accumulation of food, and its duration is correspondingly variable. The feast on this occasion is called pusu-ijuka, lit. ‘the counting of the mud’, i.e. the reckoning by which the pusu-embo (p. 211) are paid for their efforts at the funeral. The people of the deceased husband provide the bulk of the provisions for this feast, but they are assisted by the people of the widow. All the mourners who paid the deceased the final compliment of bedaubing themselves with mud, of wailing, or of digging his grave, are invited to receive their ‘payment’; but relatives on both husband's and wife's side will contribute. Apart, however, [Page [p. 218A]] PLATE XXIX [Page 219] from this paying of the nondescript body of mourners to which both groups contribute, it is evident that on the occasion of the gorukari the people of the deceased husband make some payment of food to those of the widow. In fact, amid some confusion of evidence it appears that it is virtually the people of the deceased husband who provide the feast which makes it possible for the widow to emerge from seclusion.' [925] 'Sacrifice of humans' is coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database for all logged Orokaiva rituals. [926]. However, this is based on a twentieth-century source [927].

Moralizing Supernatural Powers[edit]

♠ Moral concern is primary ♣ absent ♥
♠ Moralizing enforcement is certain ♣ absent ♥
♠ Moralizing norms are broad ♣ absent ♥
♠ Moralizing enforcement is targeted ♣ absent ♥
♠ Moralizing enforcement of rulers ♣ absent ♥
♠ Moralizing religion adopted by elites ♣ absent ♥
♠ Moralizing religion adopted by commoners ♣ absent ♥
♠ Moralizing enforcement in afterlife ♣ absent ♥
♠ Moralizing enforcement in this life ♣ absent ♥
♠ Moralizing enforcement is agentic ♣ absent ♥

These data were reviewed by expert advisors and consultants. For a detailed description of these data, refer to the relevant Analytic Narratives, reference tables, and acknowledgements page. [928] [929]

Normative Ideological precepts concerning morality/supernatural beings[edit]

Supernatural beings (e.g., gods, spirits, ancestors)

♠ Number of officially sanctioned supernatural beings ♣ polytheistic ♥ ‘Demigods’ and ancestral spirits were thought to inhabit Mt Lamington, an active volcano, and wander the countryside, occasionally causing misfortune among humans. "Ritual prohibitions limited access to the area close to the crater as there was a belief that Sumbiripa, if disturbed, would be angry. There was also a great fear of the dead who were supposedly dwelling in the mountain. It is believed that the dead wander about the countryside, where they may attack humans. Sumbiripa is dangerous, even if he does not erupt, because he can send out his ghosts to cause misfortune among men. The myth about Sumbiripa Kanekari hints at the possibility of an earlier eruption by the account it gives of the origin of the crags existing before 1951.'[930] It is unclear from the sources reviewed so far how many spirits there were. This might be difficult to quantify as different clans believed in different spirits.
♠ Omnipresent supernatural beings ♣ inferred absent ♥ Inferred from the fact that, when they first encountered Christian missionaries, the Orokaiva were skeptical of the claim of the Christian God's omnipotence. 'The Orokaiva attitude to Christianity is a complex subject which I intend to treat more fully elsewhere and falls somewhat outside the concern of our present project. It is very clear that some basic notion of Christian monotheism have not been accepted by the Orokaiva, such as for instance the notion of God's omnipotence. Orokaiva Christians believe in the existence of God and in His infinite power, but He is viewed as an addition to other powers, Who is hostile to some of these other powers, but not necessarily to others. I was told that a person ought to give up black magic after baptism, but informants dismissed my suggestion that Christianity was also opposed to curing magic. No curing magician ever ceased practising when he was baptised.'[931] It seems reasonable to infer that they were skeptical of the Christian God's omnipresence as well.
♠ Omniscient supernatural beings ♣ inferred absent ♥ Inferred from the fact that, when they first encountered Christian missionaries, the Orokaiva were skeptical of the claim of the Christian God's omnipotence. 'The Orokaiva attitude to Christianity is a complex subject which I intend to treat more fully elsewhere and falls somewhat outside the concern of our present project. It is very clear that some basic notion of Christian monotheism have not been accepted by the Orokaiva, such as for instance the notion of God's omnipotence. Orokaiva Christians believe in the existence of God and in His infinite power, but He is viewed as an addition to other powers, Who is hostile to some of these other powers, but not necessarily to others. I was told that a person ought to give up black magic after baptism, but informants dismissed my suggestion that Christianity was also opposed to curing magic. No curing magician ever ceased practising when he was baptised.'[932] It seems reasonable to infer that they were skeptical of the Christian God's omniscience as well.
♠ Omnipotent supernatural beings ♣ inferred absent ♥ Inferred from the fact that, when they first encountered Christian missionaries, the Orokaiva were skeptical of the claim of the Christian God's omnipotence. 'The Orokaiva attitude to Christianity is a complex subject which I intend to treat more fully elsewhere and falls somewhat outside the concern of our present project. It is very clear that some basic notion of Christian monotheism have not been accepted by the Orokaiva, such as for instance the notion of God's omnipotence. Orokaiva Christians believe in the existence of God and in His infinite power, but He is viewed as an addition to other powers, Who is hostile to some of these other powers, but not necessarily to others. I was told that a person ought to give up black magic after baptism, but informants dismissed my suggestion that Christianity was also opposed to curing magic. No curing magician ever ceased practising when he was baptised.'[933]
♠ High Gods (creator gods) ♣ absent ♥ The Orokaiva appear not to have had "high gods": 'Apart from the very faint hint which these last may give us there is nothing to suggest a deity or any supernatural being of independent existence, least of all a high-god. I do not know of any cosmogony, and there is no attribution of divine powers to the phenomena of nature. On the whole it will be found that Orokaiva religion concerns itself primarily with the spirits of the dead.'[934] However, they did have demi-gods, who they believed to be the source of moral principles: 'Orokaiva social philosophy differs from our own, in the first place by its refusal to recognise the authority of anyone outside the individual's extended family, a characteristic to which I shall give more attention later. If the Orokaiva, by and large, order their lives by the same moral principles, they would explain this by their common belief in certain demigods whom they all regard as their ancestors and as sources of authority, and who created certain institutions embodying moral norms to which they all subscribe. Not only do they obey the precepts of these demi-gods, they also re-enact their feats in ritual and identify with them during ceremonies, and in many of their regular expressive activities.'[935] 'I shall therefore attempt to reconstruct what these demi-gods are said to have taught the Orokaiva about social relations. This reconstruction requires a brief analysis of some myths in which these teachings are contained. The myths all refer to events in original time. I was told that men, in their primordial or pre-cultural state, were living by the top of Mount Lamington (Sumbiripa Kanekari), which is traditionally regarded by the Orokaiva as the centre of the universe (Schwimmer 1969). I collected a number of myths explaining the origin of death, strife, fire, houses, marriage, clothing and several other elements of culture. The demigods who transformed human life by introducing these gifts came ‘from the mountain’; Sumbiripa himself was the first man to die. He retired inside the mountain and all those who died later are said to stay with him inside the mountain. Hence the rumblings and tremors emitted by the volcano. Two published sources (Tomlin 1951, Benson 1955) show that these beliefs antedate the eruption of 1951.'[936] Having said this, no evidence could be found that these demi-gods (or any other supernatural being) punished or rewarded mortals on the basis of moral principles: there were ritual prohibitions against going near certain volcanic craters, lest the demi-god Sumbiripa became angry, and spirits living in the countryside were believed to occasionally attack people, but the "reason" for Sumbiripa's anger and the spirits' attack seem to stem more from transgressions against the gods than against other humans, or perhaps simply these beings' unpredictable nature. "Ritual prohibitions limited access to the area close to the crater as there was a belief that Sumbiripa, if disturbed, would be angry. There was also a great fear of the dead who were supposedly dwelling in the mountain. It is believed that the dead wander about the countryside, where they may attack humans. Sumbiripa is dangerous, even if he does not erupt, because he can send out his ghosts to cause misfortune among men. The myth about Sumbiripa Kanekari hints at the possibility of an earlier eruption by the account it gives of the origin of the crags existing before 1951.'[937] The separation between the human and 'wild' worlds was also important: 'The separation of man and pig leads immediately to the division of the world [Page 141] into two separate realms: the human world, comprising villages and gardens, and the wild world, ariri, the bush, where everything is dangerous and inimical to man, and where the ghosts (sovai) have their abode. The area friendly to man is thus reduced to a small space, whereas the area hostile to man is an infinite expanse. Thus man is forever at strife with all but a small circumscribed portion of the universe. The myth of pig-man restates in another idiom the message of the primal theft of the piece of string.'[938]

Supernatural Enforcement of Morality

♠ supernatural enforcement against harm ♣ inferred absent ♥ The Orokaiva believed demi-gods to be the source of moral principles: 'Orokaiva social philosophy differs from our own, in the first place by its refusal to recognise the authority of anyone outside the individual's extended family, a characteristic to which I shall give more attention later. If the Orokaiva, by and large, order their lives by the same moral principles, they would explain this by their common belief in certain demigods whom they all regard as their ancestors and as sources of authority, and who created certain institutions embodying moral norms to which they all subscribe. Not only do they obey the precepts of these demi-gods, they also re-enact their feats in ritual and identify with them during ceremonies, and in many of their regular expressive activities.'[939] 'I shall therefore attempt to reconstruct what these demi-gods are said to have taught the Orokaiva about social relations. This reconstruction requires a brief analysis of some myths in which these teachings are contained. The myths all refer to events in original time. I was told that men, in their primordial or pre-cultural state, were living by the top of Mount Lamington (Sumbiripa Kanekari), which is traditionally regarded by the Orokaiva as the centre of the universe (Schwimmer 1969). I collected a number of myths explaining the origin of death, strife, fire, houses, marriage, clothing and several other elements of culture. The demigods who transformed human life by introducing these gifts came ‘from the mountain’; Sumbiripa himself was the first man to die. He retired inside the mountain and all those who died later are said to stay with him inside the mountain. Hence the rumblings and tremors emitted by the volcano. Two published sources (Tomlin 1951, Benson 1955) show that these beliefs antedate the eruption of 1951.'[940] Having said this, no evidence could be found that these demi-gods (or any other supernatural being) punished or rewarded mortals on the basis of moral principles: there were ritual prohibitions against going near certain volcanic craters, lest the demi-god Sumbiripa became angry, and spirits living in the countryside were believed to occasionally attack people, but the "reason" for Sumbiripa's anger and the spirits' attack seem to stem more from transgressions against the gods than against other humans, or perhaps simply these beings' unpredictable nature. "Ritual prohibitions limited access to the area close to the crater as there was a belief that Sumbiripa, if disturbed, would be angry. There was also a great fear of the dead who were supposedly dwelling in the mountain. It is believed that the dead wander about the countryside, where they may attack humans. Sumbiripa is dangerous, even if he does not erupt, because he can send out his ghosts to cause misfortune among men. The myth about Sumbiripa Kanekari hints at the possibility of an earlier eruption by the account it gives of the origin of the crags existing before 1951.'[941] The separation between the human and 'wild' worlds was also important: 'The separation of man and pig leads immediately to the division of the world [Page 141] into two separate realms: the human world, comprising villages and gardens, and the wild world, ariri, the bush, where everything is dangerous and inimical to man, and where the ghosts (sovai) have their abode. The area friendly to man is thus reduced to a small space, whereas the area hostile to man is an infinite expanse. Thus man is forever at strife with all but a small circumscribed portion of the universe. The myth of pig-man restates in another idiom the message of the primal theft of the piece of string.'[942]
♠ supernatural enforcement of fairness ♣ ♥ The Orokaiva believed demi-gods to be the source of moral principles: 'Orokaiva social philosophy differs from our own, in the first place by its refusal to recognise the authority of anyone outside the individual's extended family, a characteristic to which I shall give more attention later. If the Orokaiva, by and large, order their lives by the same moral principles, they would explain this by their common belief in certain demigods whom they all regard as their ancestors and as sources of authority, and who created certain institutions embodying moral norms to which they all subscribe. Not only do they obey the precepts of these demi-gods, they also re-enact their feats in ritual and identify with them during ceremonies, and in many of their regular expressive activities.'[943] 'I shall therefore attempt to reconstruct what these demi-gods are said to have taught the Orokaiva about social relations. This reconstruction requires a brief analysis of some myths in which these teachings are contained. The myths all refer to events in original time. I was told that men, in their primordial or pre-cultural state, were living by the top of Mount Lamington (Sumbiripa Kanekari), which is traditionally regarded by the Orokaiva as the centre of the universe (Schwimmer 1969). I collected a number of myths explaining the origin of death, strife, fire, houses, marriage, clothing and several other elements of culture. The demigods who transformed human life by introducing these gifts came ‘from the mountain’; Sumbiripa himself was the first man to die. He retired inside the mountain and all those who died later are said to stay with him inside the mountain. Hence the rumblings and tremors emitted by the volcano. Two published sources (Tomlin 1951, Benson 1955) show that these beliefs antedate the eruption of 1951.'[944] Having said this, no evidence could be found that these demi-gods (or any other supernatural being) punished or rewarded mortals on the basis of moral principles: there were ritual prohibitions against going near certain volcanic craters, lest the demi-god Sumbiripa became angry, and spirits living in the countryside were believed to occasionally attack people, but the "reason" for Sumbiripa's anger and the spirits' attack seem to stem more from transgressions against the gods than against other humans, or perhaps simply these beings' unpredictable nature. "Ritual prohibitions limited access to the area close to the crater as there was a belief that Sumbiripa, if disturbed, would be angry. There was also a great fear of the dead who were supposedly dwelling in the mountain. It is believed that the dead wander about the countryside, where they may attack humans. Sumbiripa is dangerous, even if he does not erupt, because he can send out his ghosts to cause misfortune among men. The myth about Sumbiripa Kanekari hints at the possibility of an earlier eruption by the account it gives of the origin of the crags existing before 1951.'[945] The separation between the human and 'wild' worlds was also important: 'The separation of man and pig leads immediately to the division of the world [Page 141] into two separate realms: the human world, comprising villages and gardens, and the wild world, ariri, the bush, where everything is dangerous and inimical to man, and where the ghosts (sovai) have their abode. The area friendly to man is thus reduced to a small space, whereas the area hostile to man is an infinite expanse. Thus man is forever at strife with all but a small circumscribed portion of the universe. The myth of pig-man restates in another idiom the message of the primal theft of the piece of string.'[946]
♠ supernatural enforcement of human reciprocity ♣ inferred absent ♥ The Orokaiva believed demi-gods to be the source of moral principles: 'Orokaiva social philosophy differs from our own, in the first place by its refusal to recognise the authority of anyone outside the individual's extended family, a characteristic to which I shall give more attention later. If the Orokaiva, by and large, order their lives by the same moral principles, they would explain this by their common belief in certain demigods whom they all regard as their ancestors and as sources of authority, and who created certain institutions embodying moral norms to which they all subscribe. Not only do they obey the precepts of these demi-gods, they also re-enact their feats in ritual and identify with them during ceremonies, and in many of their regular expressive activities.'[947] 'I shall therefore attempt to reconstruct what these demi-gods are said to have taught the Orokaiva about social relations. This reconstruction requires a brief analysis of some myths in which these teachings are contained. The myths all refer to events in original time. I was told that men, in their primordial or pre-cultural state, were living by the top of Mount Lamington (Sumbiripa Kanekari), which is traditionally regarded by the Orokaiva as the centre of the universe (Schwimmer 1969). I collected a number of myths explaining the origin of death, strife, fire, houses, marriage, clothing and several other elements of culture. The demigods who transformed human life by introducing these gifts came ‘from the mountain’; Sumbiripa himself was the first man to die. He retired inside the mountain and all those who died later are said to stay with him inside the mountain. Hence the rumblings and tremors emitted by the volcano. Two published sources (Tomlin 1951, Benson 1955) show that these beliefs antedate the eruption of 1951.'[948] Having said this, no evidence could be found that these demi-gods (or any other supernatural being) punished or rewarded mortals on the basis of moral principles: there were ritual prohibitions against going near certain volcanic craters, lest the demi-god Sumbiripa became angry, and spirits living in the countryside were believed to occasionally attack people, but the "reason" for Sumbiripa's anger and the spirits' attack seem to stem more from transgressions against the gods than against other humans, or perhaps simply these beings' unpredictable nature. "Ritual prohibitions limited access to the area close to the crater as there was a belief that Sumbiripa, if disturbed, would be angry. There was also a great fear of the dead who were supposedly dwelling in the mountain. It is believed that the dead wander about the countryside, where they may attack humans. Sumbiripa is dangerous, even if he does not erupt, because he can send out his ghosts to cause misfortune among men. The myth about Sumbiripa Kanekari hints at the possibility of an earlier eruption by the account it gives of the origin of the crags existing before 1951.'[949] The separation between the human and 'wild' worlds was also important: 'The separation of man and pig leads immediately to the division of the world [Page 141] into two separate realms: the human world, comprising villages and gardens, and the wild world, ariri, the bush, where everything is dangerous and inimical to man, and where the ghosts (sovai) have their abode. The area friendly to man is thus reduced to a small space, whereas the area hostile to man is an infinite expanse. Thus man is forever at strife with all but a small circumscribed portion of the universe. The myth of pig-man restates in another idiom the message of the primal theft of the piece of string.'[950]
♠ supernatural enforcement of property rights ♣ inferred absent ♥ The Orokaiva believed demi-gods to be the source of moral principles: 'Orokaiva social philosophy differs from our own, in the first place by its refusal to recognise the authority of anyone outside the individual's extended family, a characteristic to which I shall give more attention later. If the Orokaiva, by and large, order their lives by the same moral principles, they would explain this by their common belief in certain demigods whom they all regard as their ancestors and as sources of authority, and who created certain institutions embodying moral norms to which they all subscribe. Not only do they obey the precepts of these demi-gods, they also re-enact their feats in ritual and identify with them during ceremonies, and in many of their regular expressive activities.'[951] 'I shall therefore attempt to reconstruct what these demi-gods are said to have taught the Orokaiva about social relations. This reconstruction requires a brief analysis of some myths in which these teachings are contained. The myths all refer to events in original time. I was told that men, in their primordial or pre-cultural state, were living by the top of Mount Lamington (Sumbiripa Kanekari), which is traditionally regarded by the Orokaiva as the centre of the universe (Schwimmer 1969). I collected a number of myths explaining the origin of death, strife, fire, houses, marriage, clothing and several other elements of culture. The demigods who transformed human life by introducing these gifts came ‘from the mountain’; Sumbiripa himself was the first man to die. He retired inside the mountain and all those who died later are said to stay with him inside the mountain. Hence the rumblings and tremors emitted by the volcano. Two published sources (Tomlin 1951, Benson 1955) show that these beliefs antedate the eruption of 1951.'[952] Having said this, no evidence could be found that these demi-gods (or any other supernatural being) punished or rewarded mortals on the basis of moral principles: there were ritual prohibitions against going near certain volcanic craters, lest the demi-god Sumbiripa became angry, and spirits living in the countryside were believed to occasionally attack people, but the "reason" for Sumbiripa's anger and the spirits' attack seem to stem more from transgressions against the gods than against other humans, or perhaps simply these beings' unpredictable nature. "Ritual prohibitions limited access to the area close to the crater as there was a belief that Sumbiripa, if disturbed, would be angry. There was also a great fear of the dead who were supposedly dwelling in the mountain. It is believed that the dead wander about the countryside, where they may attack humans. Sumbiripa is dangerous, even if he does not erupt, because he can send out his ghosts to cause misfortune among men. The myth about Sumbiripa Kanekari hints at the possibility of an earlier eruption by the account it gives of the origin of the crags existing before 1951.'[953] The separation between the human and 'wild' worlds was also important: 'The separation of man and pig leads immediately to the division of the world [Page 141] into two separate realms: the human world, comprising villages and gardens, and the wild world, ariri, the bush, where everything is dangerous and inimical to man, and where the ghosts (sovai) have their abode. The area friendly to man is thus reduced to a small space, whereas the area hostile to man is an infinite expanse. Thus man is forever at strife with all but a small circumscribed portion of the universe. The myth of pig-man restates in another idiom the message of the primal theft of the piece of string.'[954] In the case of property rights specifically, it is worth noting that owners of garden plots built markers in order to protect them from intruders, and it is possible intruders were believed to be punished supernaturally, though this is not made explicit in the following quotes. '(1) The commonest is papara or ese, the frond of coco-nut palm tied about the butt, which means that no one is to [Page 324] climb for nuts. (2) The heri is a strip of bark or a liana tied to uprights and encircling a house or some forbidden ground. (3) A harihari is some object, usually leaf or twig, placed in the cleft of a split stick and set up, e.g., at the mouth of a creek as a sign of a fishing right. (4) Inja is simply a few handfuls of grass laid across a track to bar the passage. We might include (5) the naterari and pamba (p. 226), which serve to mark a village tabu on the coco-nuts, and (6) logically enough the ordinary garden boundary, tani, which consists merely of a series of tree-trunks or branches laid on the ground between adjacent plots. These are all regarded quite strictly: no man would step over an inja or take a short cut across an area enclosed by a heri. Less regular marks which may serve as reminders for some casual rule are observed with equal stringency. For instance, I have seen an eight of diamonds wedged in a split stick and set up in a village to forbid the playing of cards; it had been erected by a man of influence who has somehow acquired conscientious scruples regarding the forbidden game. The sanctions for the strict observance of these marks will be discussed presently; the signs themselves are described here merely to show the existence of tangible safeguards, principally, but not always, of the law of property.'[955]
♠ supernatural enforcement of kinship obligations ♣ inferred absent ♥ The Orokaiva believed demi-gods to be the source of moral principles: 'Orokaiva social philosophy differs from our own, in the first place by its refusal to recognise the authority of anyone outside the individual's extended family, a characteristic to which I shall give more attention later. If the Orokaiva, by and large, order their lives by the same moral principles, they would explain this by their common belief in certain demigods whom they all regard as their ancestors and as sources of authority, and who created certain institutions embodying moral norms to which they all subscribe. Not only do they obey the precepts of these demi-gods, they also re-enact their feats in ritual and identify with them during ceremonies, and in many of their regular expressive activities.'[956] 'I shall therefore attempt to reconstruct what these demi-gods are said to have taught the Orokaiva about social relations. This reconstruction requires a brief analysis of some myths in which these teachings are contained. The myths all refer to events in original time. I was told that men, in their primordial or pre-cultural state, were living by the top of Mount Lamington (Sumbiripa Kanekari), which is traditionally regarded by the Orokaiva as the centre of the universe (Schwimmer 1969). I collected a number of myths explaining the origin of death, strife, fire, houses, marriage, clothing and several other elements of culture. The demigods who transformed human life by introducing these gifts came ‘from the mountain’; Sumbiripa himself was the first man to die. He retired inside the mountain and all those who died later are said to stay with him inside the mountain. Hence the rumblings and tremors emitted by the volcano. Two published sources (Tomlin 1951, Benson 1955) show that these beliefs antedate the eruption of 1951.'[957] Having said this, no evidence could be found that these demi-gods (or any other supernatural being) punished or rewarded mortals on the basis of moral principles: there were ritual prohibitions against going near certain volcanic craters, lest the demi-god Sumbiripa became angry, and spirits living in the countryside were believed to occasionally attack people, but the "reason" for Sumbiripa's anger and the spirits' attack seem to stem more from transgressions against the gods than against other humans, or perhaps simply these beings' unpredictable nature. "Ritual prohibitions limited access to the area close to the crater as there was a belief that Sumbiripa, if disturbed, would be angry. There was also a great fear of the dead who were supposedly dwelling in the mountain. It is believed that the dead wander about the countryside, where they may attack humans. Sumbiripa is dangerous, even if he does not erupt, because he can send out his ghosts to cause misfortune among men. The myth about Sumbiripa Kanekari hints at the possibility of an earlier eruption by the account it gives of the origin of the crags existing before 1951.'[958] The separation between the human and 'wild' worlds was also important: 'The separation of man and pig leads immediately to the division of the world [Page 141] into two separate realms: the human world, comprising villages and gardens, and the wild world, ariri, the bush, where everything is dangerous and inimical to man, and where the ghosts (sovai) have their abode. The area friendly to man is thus reduced to a small space, whereas the area hostile to man is an infinite expanse. Thus man is forever at strife with all but a small circumscribed portion of the universe. The myth of pig-man restates in another idiom the message of the primal theft of the piece of string.'[959] In the case of this specific variable, it is worth noting that men were expected to conform to avoidance taboos when interacting with their parents-in-law, specifically name avoidance. However, again, we have found no evidence of magical sanctions regarding name avoidance.
♠ supernatural enforcement of in-group loyalty ♣ inferred absent ♥ The Orokaiva believed demi-gods to be the source of moral principles: 'Orokaiva social philosophy differs from our own, in the first place by its refusal to recognise the authority of anyone outside the individual's extended family, a characteristic to which I shall give more attention later. If the Orokaiva, by and large, order their lives by the same moral principles, they would explain this by their common belief in certain demigods whom they all regard as their ancestors and as sources of authority, and who created certain institutions embodying moral norms to which they all subscribe. Not only do they obey the precepts of these demi-gods, they also re-enact their feats in ritual and identify with them during ceremonies, and in many of their regular expressive activities.'[960] 'I shall therefore attempt to reconstruct what these demi-gods are said to have taught the Orokaiva about social relations. This reconstruction requires a brief analysis of some myths in which these teachings are contained. The myths all refer to events in original time. I was told that men, in their primordial or pre-cultural state, were living by the top of Mount Lamington (Sumbiripa Kanekari), which is traditionally regarded by the Orokaiva as the centre of the universe (Schwimmer 1969). I collected a number of myths explaining the origin of death, strife, fire, houses, marriage, clothing and several other elements of culture. The demigods who transformed human life by introducing these gifts came ‘from the mountain’; Sumbiripa himself was the first man to die. He retired inside the mountain and all those who died later are said to stay with him inside the mountain. Hence the rumblings and tremors emitted by the volcano. Two published sources (Tomlin 1951, Benson 1955) show that these beliefs antedate the eruption of 1951.'[961] Having said this, no evidence could be found that these demi-gods (or any other supernatural being) punished or rewarded mortals on the basis of moral principles: there were ritual prohibitions against going near certain volcanic craters, lest the demi-god Sumbiripa became angry, and spirits living in the countryside were believed to occasionally attack people, but the "reason" for Sumbiripa's anger and the spirits' attack seem to stem more from transgressions against the gods than against other humans, or perhaps simply these beings' unpredictable nature. "Ritual prohibitions limited access to the area close to the crater as there was a belief that Sumbiripa, if disturbed, would be angry. There was also a great fear of the dead who were supposedly dwelling in the mountain. It is believed that the dead wander about the countryside, where they may attack humans. Sumbiripa is dangerous, even if he does not erupt, because he can send out his ghosts to cause misfortune among men. Thus man is forever at strife with all but a small circumscribed portion of the universe. The myth of pig-man restates in another idiom the message of the primal theft of the piece of string.'[963]
♠ supernatural enforcement of respect ♣ inferred absent ♥ The Orokaiva believed demi-gods to be the source of moral principles: 'Orokaiva social philosophy differs from our own, in the first place by its refusal to recognise the authority of anyone outside the individual's extended family, a characteristic to which I shall give more attention later. If the Orokaiva, by and large, order their lives by the same moral principles, they would explain this by their common belief in certain demigods whom they all regard as their ancestors and as sources of authority, and who created certain institutions embodying moral norms to which they all subscribe. Not only do they obey the precepts of these demi-gods, they also re-enact their feats in ritual and identify with them during ceremonies, and in many of their regular expressive activities.'[964] 'I shall therefore attempt to reconstruct what these demi-gods are said to have taught the Orokaiva about social relations. This reconstruction requires a brief analysis of some myths in which these teachings are contained. The myths all refer to events in original time. I was told that men, in their primordial or pre-cultural state, were living by the top of Mount Lamington (Sumbiripa Kanekari), which is traditionally regarded by the Orokaiva as the centre of the universe (Schwimmer 1969). I collected a number of myths explaining the origin of death, strife, fire, houses, marriage, clothing and several other elements of culture. The demigods who transformed human life by introducing these gifts came ‘from the mountain’; Sumbiripa himself was the first man to die. He retired inside the mountain and all those who died later are said to stay with him inside the mountain. Hence the rumblings and tremors emitted by the volcano. Two published sources (Tomlin 1951, Benson 1955) show that these beliefs antedate the eruption of 1951.'[965] Having said this, no evidence could be found that these demi-gods (or any other supernatural being) punished or rewarded mortals on the basis of moral principles: there were ritual prohibitions against going near certain volcanic craters, lest the demi-god Sumbiripa became angry, and spirits living in the countryside were believed to occasionally attack people, but the "reason" for Sumbiripa's anger and the spirits' attack seem to stem more from transgressions against the gods than against other humans, or perhaps simply these beings' unpredictable nature. "Ritual prohibitions limited access to the area close to the crater as there was a belief that Sumbiripa, if disturbed, would be angry. There was also a great fear of the dead who were supposedly dwelling in the mountain. It is believed that the dead wander about the countryside, where they may attack humans. Sumbiripa is dangerous, even if he does not erupt, because he can send out his ghosts to cause misfortune among men. The myth about Sumbiripa Kanekari hints at the possibility of an earlier eruption by the account it gives of the origin of the crags existing before 1951.'[966] The separation between the human and 'wild' worlds was also important: 'The separation of man and pig leads immediately to the division of the world [Page 141] into two separate realms: the human world, comprising villages and gardens, and the wild world, ariri, the bush, where everything is dangerous and inimical to man, and where the ghosts (sovai) have their abode. The area friendly to man is thus reduced to a small space, whereas the area hostile to man is an infinite expanse. Thus man is forever at strife with all but a small circumscribed portion of the universe. The myth of pig-man restates in another idiom the message of the primal theft of the piece of string.'[967] In the specific case of this variable, it's worth noting that Orokaiva society was patrilineal, but men also treated their maternal uncle with respect. Big men were respected in their communities and organized collective ceremonies, but were not owed much deference in general. Special ceremonial insignia were awarded to slayers and other accomplished individuals, but we have found no evidence that respect towards them was supernaturally enforced.
♠ supernatural enforcement of bravery ♣ inferred absent ♥ The Orokaiva believed demi-gods to be the source of moral principles: 'Orokaiva social philosophy differs from our own, in the first place by its refusal to recognise the authority of anyone outside the individual's extended family, a characteristic to which I shall give more attention later. If the Orokaiva, by and large, order their lives by the same moral principles, they would explain this by their common belief in certain demigods whom they all regard as their ancestors and as sources of authority, and who created certain institutions embodying moral norms to which they all subscribe. Not only do they obey the precepts of these demi-gods, they also re-enact their feats in ritual and identify with them during ceremonies, and in many of their regular expressive activities.'[968] 'I shall therefore attempt to reconstruct what these demi-gods are said to have taught the Orokaiva about social relations. This reconstruction requires a brief analysis of some myths in which these teachings are contained. The myths all refer to events in original time. I was told that men, in their primordial or pre-cultural state, were living by the top of Mount Lamington (Sumbiripa Kanekari), which is traditionally regarded by the Orokaiva as the centre of the universe (Schwimmer 1969). I collected a number of myths explaining the origin of death, strife, fire, houses, marriage, clothing and several other elements of culture. The demigods who transformed human life by introducing these gifts came ‘from the mountain’; Sumbiripa himself was the first man to die. He retired inside the mountain and all those who died later are said to stay with him inside the mountain. Hence the rumblings and tremors emitted by the volcano. Two published sources (Tomlin 1951, Benson 1955) show that these beliefs antedate the eruption of 1951.'[969] Having said this, no evidence could be found that these demi-gods (or any other supernatural being) punished or rewarded mortals on the basis of moral principles: there were ritual prohibitions against going near certain volcanic craters, lest the demi-god Sumbiripa became angry, and spirits living in the countryside were believed to occasionally attack people, but the "reason" for Sumbiripa's anger and the spirits' attack seem to stem more from transgressions against the gods than against other humans, or perhaps simply these beings' unpredictable nature. "Ritual prohibitions limited access to the area close to the crater as there was a belief that Sumbiripa, if disturbed, would be angry. There was also a great fear of the dead who were supposedly dwelling in the mountain. It is believed that the dead wander about the countryside, where they may attack humans. Sumbiripa is dangerous, even if he does not erupt, because he can send out his ghosts to cause misfortune among men. The myth about Sumbiripa Kanekari hints at the possibility of an earlier eruption by the account it gives of the origin of the crags existing before 1951.'[970] The separation between the human and 'wild' worlds was also important: 'The separation of man and pig leads immediately to the division of the world [Page 141] into two separate realms: the human world, comprising villages and gardens, and the wild world, ariri, the bush, where everything is dangerous and inimical to man, and where the ghosts (sovai) have their abode. The area friendly to man is thus reduced to a small space, whereas the area hostile to man is an infinite expanse. Thus man is forever at strife with all but a small circumscribed portion of the universe. The myth of pig-man restates in another idiom the message of the primal theft of the piece of string.'[971] In the specific case of this variable, fierceness and bravery in battle were valued. These values were reinforced during the socialization and initiation of young boys. Cowards were ridiculed. However, again, we have found no evidence of supernatural enforcement in the reviewed material.
♠ supernatural enforcement of purity ♣ present ♥ absent/present/unknown. Slayers had to observe taboos before undergoing ritual purification. Some sources state that these rituals were thought to defend the slayer against supernatural retaliation by the spirit of the individual he had killed: 'Again the slayer must perform certain rites and observe certain tabus. He must not drink pure water out of the river, but only that which has been stirred up and made muddy by the feet of a non-slayer. He must not eat taro cooked in the pot, but only that which has been roasted in the open fire. He must abstain from sexual intercourse. These restrictions lasted for a few days and then the slayer ate the same purificatory stew (suna) which is given to initiates at the end of their seclusion (see p. 193). Among the Binandele I witnessed a mock demonstration of a peculiar rite which immediately preceded the eating of the suna. The slayer climbs into a small tree which contains a nest of those large and aggressive insects commonly called ‘green’ ants. The tree should properly be of the kind called Bobo, which [Page 175] is always swarming with them. While he crouches in a fork of the tree, branches are broken and laid over him so that he is almost completely covered and thoroughly bitten. Having endured this for some time, he climbs down and eats the suna, steaming himself over the dish and sponging his joints with handfuls of the stewed leaves. Another rite (also performed at the end of the initiate's seclusion) was to break a coco-nut above the slayer and souse his head with the milk.'[972] 'It seems likely that all these observances and tabus are in a sense not only purificatory but defensive. As a rule, informants have no explanation to offer, but I have been informed directly that they are meant to drive away the asisi, or spirit, of the slain man. In support of this view I may quote what W. N. Beaver has written: ‘I am not disposed to the sole view that the killer is “unclean”. It seems to me rather that rites are necessary to throw off the power of the ghost or ghosts of the slain….’'[973] Initiands also underwent ritual purification. Initiates had to observe food taboos and were believed to suffer misfortune when breaking them (such as baldness): 'The initiates gather round the dish of suna and bend over it so as to be fumigated by the rising steam. They hold their hands in the steam, and then withdrawing them massage their joints. They take handfuls of the hot leaves and apply them to their private parts, their hip-joints, their elbows, their arm-pits, &c. They end by eating the stew. The other villagers stand by, themselves partaking and sponging their bodies with the leaves. The suna is sometimes set out in a wooden dish (teva) and a hot stone placed in it to increase the volume of steam, while the initiates stooping over the dish may be covered with pandanus mats to give them something like a Turkish bath.'[974] 'After partaking of the suna the initiate is at liberty to resume his full diet. (During the last two or three days he has eaten nothing but banana and sugar-cane.) But even so he must be cautious. Before passing him a piece of taro one of the elders will pass it under his legs-a queer precaution which appears again and again in Orokaiva ceremonies, either as a purification or as a prophylaxis. Having thus received the taro, the hungry initiate must nibble it only and put it aside for a while. Furthermore, he must not handle it, but convey it to his mouth on a piece of stick as a fork. If he should handle it and afterwards scratch his head the penalty would be the severe one of baldness.'[975] In the colonial period, initiates of the Taro cult also had to observe food taboos. Breaking these taboos was thought to cause the loss of the supernatural healing powers acquired through initiation and also resulted in misfortune: 'The disciple sometimes has to undergo a kind of probation. Having once acquired the Taro he must, for a considerable period (until, indeed, it is thoroughly established or ingrained into him), observe certain taboos. The chief of these is the taboo against washing. There are instances in which the enthusiastic acolyte forgoes the pleasures of a midday bathe for as long as eight months. When the Taro cult had crept insidiously into one of the mission schools, its presence was first [Page 33] detected-among a class of well-grown young females-by the missionary's nostrils. The reason for this taboo seems to lie in the supposed efficacy of running water, which will not only cleanse away impurity, but also carry off and dissipate the mana of the prophet. It is in keeping with this idea that the Taro novice be allowed, if necessary, to wash in still, swampy water. The taboos which are incumbent upon the professing Taro man will call for further description. The probationary taboo against washing should normally come to an end only with the permission of the superior who has been responsible for the novice's entry into the cult; but it must not be supposed that this rule is carried out in any strictness.'[976] 'It sometimes happens that an aspirant grows tired of the restrictions which are imposed upon him; and even a qualified Taro man may voluntarily break through them and ipso facto relinquish his status. Thus we find ‘resignations’, sometimes because of the constant tiresome jipari, sometimes because of the taboo upon bathing, sometimes because the temptation of forbidden foods cannot be resisted. One man said he had given over the Taro because he was hungry for eels, ohiti, which are banned to the faithful. Another, wounded in a village affray and temporarily incapacitated, had obtained a sort of absolution from the man who introduced him to the cult, and by bathing in a stream thus automatically ceased to be a Taro man.'[977] 'As certain medicines are prescribed for the Taro man either to increase his own power or else to be transmitted by him to the taro itself, so on the other hand there are many restrictions placed upon him for negative, but similar, reasons. He is in fact dieted with some strictness, and the reasons which govern these food taboos are worth considering. In a great majority of cases the man who observes the taboo is completely ignorant of any logical basis for it: he has learnt it by rote, so to speak, having received it as part of the cult from his instructor, and not only has he never heard a sensible argument in its favour, but, if taxed for such an argument, can think of none save ad verecundiam. But sometimes one meets a native with a spark of imagination. The explanations which he may give of the taboos are not necessarily the original ones, but notwithstanding they are typical native explanations, and at least as good as the original. A few examples will show what real grounds there are for the prohibitions. Pauri, the cuscus, is forbidden because of the yellowish colour of its fur, dappled with brown spots. Should the Taro man eat Pauri it is likely that the taro leaf will develop similar properties instead of keeping the rich green colour which is indicative of health. Auja, the red pandanus seed, and sasaru, a kind of frog, are tabooed for the same reason. It was explained that the frog, when cooked, is of a yellow-brown colour which is unwholesome not so much for the Taro man as for the taro. Ambe, or sago, was avoided in some quarters because the roots at the butt of the palm are often exposed in a way that is not desirable for the taro tuber. Imbaga the crocodile, wotomo a kind of flat fish, and ohiti the eel were ‘too heavy’. The idea of weight seems to be associated very commonly with sickness, and it is felt that the Taro man who ate creatures in which this quality is so obviously embodied, would be endangering his [Page 46] powers of healing. There are many more food taboos. Some of them may well enough be survivals from the Baigona cult (which placed a prohibition upon almost all creeping things), as they appear to have no very obvious bearing on Taro. Certain kinds of the taro itself were held to be injurious-only so, indeed, since the institution of the cult, for previously these forbidden varieties were eaten without any untoward result; Mr. Elder says they were given to his mission boys, ‘who being unbelievers thrived on them’.'[978] 'The taboo upon bathing has already been mentioned. It was evidently observed with a certain strictness and, in some cases at least, a breach of the taboo meant more than the mere loss of power. One Taro man of importance gave the following explanation for a lameness in the knee which had crippled him for eight months. Having used his spear too effectively in a village fight he was removed to jail, and there, under a regimen which took no heed of his priestly obligations, compelled to cut his hair and wash the smears of mud and white ochre off his body. The unfortunate prisoner's explanation still leaves one mystified: the dirt, mud, and paint being washed off the remainder of his body, concentrated in his knee and there brought on his lameness.'[979] The Taro spirit was also thought to harm non-specialist believers if taboos were violated: 'In the doctrines of the new cult it was maintained that a man might give offence to the actual taro spirit, and be punished by it with a sickness. Thus there were certain varieties of taro, perfectly wholesome, which were made taboo to the layman of the new cult. They were called koropa, or strong, and he ate them at the risk of illness. So again, according to Buninia and Yaviripa, taro might not be pulled without first consulting the Taro men. The taro spirits would be angry with one who was so disrespectful as to break this rule, and would enter into him and lay him up with a sickness.'[980] Mt Lamington, where spirits were thought to reside, was taboo. Access to the area was limited through ritual prohibitions in order not to anger the spirits. The eruption of Mt Lamington in 1951 was interpreted as punishment for breaches of taboo, such as the use of firearms near the volcano (see above). We have considered the above to incorporate both purity and piety.
♠ general supernatural enforcement of morality ♣ inferred absent ♥ The Orokaiva believed demi-gods to be the source of moral principles: 'Orokaiva social philosophy differs from our own, in the first place by its refusal to recognise the authority of anyone outside the individual's extended family, a characteristic to which I shall give more attention later. If the Orokaiva, by and large, order their lives by the same moral principles, they would explain this by their common belief in certain demigods whom they all regard as their ancestors and as sources of authority, and who created certain institutions embodying moral norms to which they all subscribe. Not only do they obey the precepts of these demi-gods, they also re-enact their feats in ritual and identify with them during ceremonies, and in many of their regular expressive activities.'[981] 'I shall therefore attempt to reconstruct what these demi-gods are said to have taught the Orokaiva about social relations. This reconstruction requires a brief analysis of some myths in which these teachings are contained. The myths all refer to events in original time. I was told that men, in their primordial or pre-cultural state, were living by the top of Mount Lamington (Sumbiripa Kanekari), which is traditionally regarded by the Orokaiva as the centre of the universe (Schwimmer 1969). I collected a number of myths explaining the origin of death, strife, fire, houses, marriage, clothing and several other elements of culture. The demigods who transformed human life by introducing these gifts came ‘from the mountain’; Sumbiripa himself was the first man to die. He retired inside the mountain and all those who died later are said to stay with him inside the mountain. Hence the rumblings and tremors emitted by the volcano. Two published sources (Tomlin 1951, Benson 1955) show that these beliefs antedate the eruption of 1951.'[982] Having said this, no evidence could be found that these demi-gods (or any other supernatural being) punished or rewarded mortals on the basis of moral principles: there were ritual prohibitions against going near certain volcanic craters, lest the demi-god Sumbiripa became angry, and spirits living in the countryside were believed to occasionally attack people, but the "reason" for Sumbiripa's anger and the spirits' attack seem to stem more from transgressions against the gods than against other humans, or perhaps simply these beings' unpredictable nature. "Ritual prohibitions limited access to the area close to the crater as there was a belief that Sumbiripa, if disturbed, would be angry. There was also a great fear of the dead who were supposedly dwelling in the mountain. It is believed that the dead wander about the countryside, where they may attack humans. Sumbiripa is dangerous, even if he does not erupt, because he can send out his ghosts to cause misfortune among men.
